{{Infobox bus accident |title=2009 Taconic State Parkway crash |date=Sunday, July 26, 2009, 1:35 pm EDT |location=[[Taconic State Parkway]], [[Mount Pleasant, New York|Mount Pleasant]], near [[Briarcliff Manor, New York]] |vehicles=2003 Ford Windstar minivan
2004 Chevrolet TrailBlazer SUV
2002 Chevrolet Tracker SUV |deaths=8 |injuries=3 |}} The '''2009 Taconic State Parkway crash''' was a [[traffic collision]] that occurred shortly after {{nowrap|1:30 p.m.}} on Sunday, July 26, 2009, on the [[Taconic State Parkway]] in the town of [[Mount Pleasant, New York|Mount Pleasant]], near the village of [[Briarcliff Manor, New York|Briarcliff Manor]], [[New York (state)|New York]].{{cite web|last=Snedeker|first=Louise|title=Wrong Way Tragedy: Supporting First Responders|url=http://rivertowns.dailyvoice.com/news/wrong-way-tragedy-supporting-first-responders|publisher=The Rivertowns Daily Voice|accessdate=19 July 2012}} Eight people were killed when a minivan being driven by 36-year-old Diane Schuler traveled 1.7 miles in the wrong direction on the parkway and collided head-on with an oncoming SUV. The deaths included Schuler, her daughter and three nieces, and the three passengers in the oncoming SUV.{{cite web|last=Lee|first=Tien-Shun|title=Wrong Way Tragedy: Shock, Mystery Still Linger|url=http://briarcliff.dailyvoice.com/wheels/wrong-way-tragedy-shock-mystery-still-linger|publisher=The Briarcliff Daily Voice|accessdate=3 July 2012}} The crash was the worst fatal motor vehicle accident to occur in [[Westchester County, New York|Westchester County]]{{cite web|last=Michelin|first=Robert|title=Wrong Way Tragedy: First Responders Look Back|url=http://briarcliff.dailyvoice.com/neighbors/wrong-way-tragedy-first-responders-look-back|publisher=The Briarcliff Daily Voice}} since July 22, 1934, when a bus accident in [[Ossining (town), New York|Ossining]] claimed 20 lives.Ali, A., [http://www.lohud.com/article/2009907260372 "4 Kids, 4 Adults Die on Taconic]," ''The Journal News'' (Lower Hudson), July 26, 2009.{{cite web|title=Bus Owners Ask Change in Venue |author= |url=http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%205/Brooklyn%20NY%20Daily%20Eagle/Brooklyn%20NY%20Daily%20Eagle%201934%20Grayscale/Brooklyn%20NY%20Daily%20Eagle%201934%20a%20Grayscale%20-%200148.pdf |work= |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5jq7dGDxS?url=http://fultonhistory.com/Newspaper%205/Brooklyn%20NY%20Daily%20Eagle/Brooklyn%20NY%20Daily%20Eagle%201934%20Grayscale/Brooklyn%20NY%20Daily%20Eagle%201934%20a%20Grayscale%20-%200148.pdf |archivedate=2009-09-16 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-09-13 |df= }} The ensuing investigation into the crash's cause received nationwide attention. [[Toxicology]] tests conducted by the [[medical examiner]] revealed that Schuler was heavily intoxicated with both [[alcohol (drug)|alcohol]] and [[marijuana]] at the time of the crash. Schuler's husband, Daniel, has consistently denied that she used drugs or alcohol "excessively", and has made multiple national media appearances to defend his wife and call for further investigation into other possible medical causes for her erratic driving. An independent investigator hired by the Schuler family obtained [[DNA]] testing and toxicology testing of Schuler's samples, and also confirmed the results of the original testing.{{cite web|url=http://transcripts.cnn.com/TRANSCRIPTS/1107/26/ijvm.01.html|title=Interview with Tom Ruskin|work=cnn.com}} ==Day of incident== [[File:01-03 Ford Windstar Sport.jpg|thumb|2003 [[Ford Windstar]]]] At approximately {{nowrap|9:30 a.m.}} on Sunday, July 26, 2009, 36-year-old Diane Schuler left the Hunter Lake Campground in [[Parksville, New York|Parksville]], [[New York (state)|New York]], in a red 2003 [[Ford Windstar]] that belonged to her brother. Riding with Schuler were her 5-year-old son and 2-year-old daughter, and her brother's three daughters (ages 8, 7, and 5). Her husband, Daniel Schuler, left the campground at the same time in a separate vehicle since he had a pickup truck and took the dog with him.[http://www.nypost.com/seven/08052009/news/regionalnews/crash_mom_was_fully_loaded_183033.htm "Crash Mom Was Fully 'Loaded'"], ''New York Post'', August 5, 2009.[http://wcbstv.com/topstories/diane.schuler.crash.2.1119932.html NY Police: Woman Was OK at Restaurant Before Crash] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090816232116/http://wcbstv.com/topstories/diane.schuler.crash.2.1119932.html |date=2009-08-16 }}, WCBS, Aug 7, 2009.Fitz-Gibbon J, Bandler J., [http://www.lohud.com/article/20090803/NEWS01/308030034/1020/rss0103 "A Week after the Crash, Questions Remain]," ''The Journal News'' (Lower Hudson), August 3, 2009. A co-owner of the campground later said that Diane Schuler appeared [[sobriety|sober]] when she departed.Gendar, A., Chapman, B., Goldsmith, S.,[http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2009/08/04/2009-08-04_diane_schuler_mom_who_drove_van_wrong_way_on_the_taconic_killing_8_was_drunk_on_.html Driver in deadly Taconic crash Diane Schuler was drunk, had marijuana in system], New York Daily News, August 4, 2009.[http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20090805/NEWS/908050350 "Taconic-Crash Mom Drunk, High, Tests Reveal]," ''Times Herald-Record'', August 5, 2009. On the way to [[West Babylon, New York|West Babylon]], Schuler stopped at a [[McDonald's]] fast-food restaurant and a Sunoco gas station in [[Liberty (village), New York|Liberty]]. While at the gas station, on surveillance video with no sound, it was reported that she attempted to buy [[over-the-counter drug|over-the-counter]] pain-relief medication, possibly for a painful tooth, but the gas station did not sell any.[http://www.newsday.com/private-eye-wrong-way-driver-stopped-at-ny-store-1.1368102 "Private Eye: Wrong-Way Driver Stopped at NY Store]," ''Associated Press'', August 14, 2009.Lam, C., [http://www.newsday.com/long-island/nassau/schuler-s-husband-meets-again-with-state-police-1.1371064 Schuler's husband meets again with State Police], New York Newsday, August 14, 2009. Schuler left Liberty just after {{nowrap|11 a.m.}}, traveling along [[New York State Route 17|Route 17]]/[[Interstate 86 (east)|Interstate 86]] and the New York Thruway ([[Interstate 87 (New York)|Interstate 87]]), entering the [[Ramapo, New York|Ramapo]] service area, and crossing the [[Tappan Zee Bridge (1955–2017)|Tappan Zee Bridge]], heading east. Several witnesses later reported seeing a red minivan driving aggressively on Route 17/Interstate 86 and Interstate 87, including aggressively tailgating, flashing headlights, honking the horn, moving in and out of lanes, and straddling two lanes. At {{nowrap|11:37 a.m.}}, Schuler called Warren Hance, her brother and father of her three nieces, from the van. She reportedly told him that they were being delayed by [[traffic]].Baker, A., and Kovaleski, S., [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/08/nyregion/08crash.html "Alcohol and Phone-Call Details in Wrong-Way Crash]," ''The New York Times'', August 8, 2009. According to a police report, Schuler was seen by witnesses at approximately {{nowrap|11:45 a.m.}} by the side of the road with her hands on her knees, as if [[vomiting]]; she was seen again in the same position a short time later, north of the Ramapo rest stop.Crowley, Kieran. [http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/taconic_ma_twice_car_sick_BAhRyIYETX2kVHN1IDeseL "Taconic ma twice car sick."] New York Post, 2009-11-09. [[File:Chevrolet TrailBlazer EXT -- 12-21-2011 2.jpg|thumb|2004 [[Chevrolet TrailBlazer]]]] At about {{nowrap|1 p.m.}}, another call was made to Hance from Schuler's cell phone. During this call, one of Schuler's nieces reportedly told her father that Schuler was having trouble seeing and speaking clearly. Schuler herself then talked to Hance and said that she was disoriented and could not see clearly. Police believe that the car was stopped in a pull-off area beyond the Tappan Zee Bridge [[Toll road|tollbooth]]s for at least part of this call. Hance reportedly told Schuler to stay off the road while he came to meet them; follow-up calls from Hance to Schuler were not answered. For some unknown reason, she left her cell phone on the highway, which was found by another motorist by the side of the road near the toll lanes of the Tappan Zee Bridge.Cohen S, and Bandler J, [http://lohud.com/article/20090730/NEWS02/907300377/-1/SPORTS "Driver Spoke on Phone with Brother 25 Minutes Before Fatal Crash] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090817162115/http://lohud.com/article/20090730/NEWS02/907300377/-1/SPORTS |date=2009-08-17 }}," ''The Journal News'' (Lower Hudson), July 30, 2009.Baker, A., [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/03/nyregion/03crash.html "Investigators Reconstruct a Route That Led to 8 Deaths]," ''The New York Times'', August 2, 2009. Investigators were trying to determine how (and why) Schuler got from the bridge to the [[Taconic State Parkway]] ramps near [[Briarcliff Manor, New York|Briarcliff Manor]], New York, which is from where the next information in this timeline comes. At {{nowrap|1:33 p.m.}}, two drivers called [[9-1-1|911]] after noticing Schuler's van edging onto the northbound exit ramp of the Taconic State Parkway near Briarcliff Manor. The end of the exit ramp ({{coord|41.142734|-73.814038|format=dms|type:event|display=inline}}), at the intersection with Pleasantville Road, is marked with two signs that read "[[Road signs in the United States#R5 Series: Exclusionary|Do Not Enter]]" and two signs that read "[[Road signs in the United States#R6 Series: One Way and Divided Highway|One Way]]".Foderado, L.W., Schweber, N.,[https://www.nytimes.com/2009/07/28/nyregion/28crash.html?_r=1&ref=nyregion "Bad Omens, a Fateful Turn, and 8 Lives Lost]," ''The New York Times'', July 28, 2009.Marchant, R., [http://lohud.com/article/20090728/NEWS01/907280355/-1/SPORTS "Wrong-way Turn onto Taconic Puzzles Many] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090731111602/http://lohud.com/article/20090728/NEWS01/907280355/-1/SPORTS |date=2009-07-31 }}," ''The Journal News'' (Lower Hudson), July 28, 2009 (Video). Within the next minute, four more 911 calls were placed by motorists who reported that a car was traveling the wrong way down the [[parkway]] going approximately 75-85 mph. [[File:99-04_Chevrolet_Tracker.jpg|thumb|2002 [[Chevrolet Tracker (Americas)|Chevrolet Tracker]]]] The van traveled south for 1.7 miles in the parkway's northbound [[passing lane]] before colliding head-on, at approximately {{nowrap|1:35 p.m.}}, with a 2004 [[Chevrolet TrailBlazer]], which then struck a 2002 [[Chevrolet Tracker]]. At the time of impact, Schuler was traveling approximately 85 mph. Schuler, her daughter, and two of her nieces were dead at the scene of the crash (the children did not appear to have been in car seats, or even to have had [[seatbelt]]s fastened), along with the three men in the TrailBlazer: 81-year-old Michael Bastardi, his 49-year-old son Guy, and their friend, 74-year-old Dan Longo. The two occupants of the Tracker suffered only minor injuries. Schuler's severely injured third niece and Schuler's 5-year-old son Bryan were taken to area hospitals, where the niece died later that day.Gorman, S., [http://lohud.com/article/20090810/NEWS02/908100324/-1/SPORTS "Child's Helpless Eyes Haunt Ossining Firefighter] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090813094605/http://lohud.com/article/20090810/NEWS02/908100324/-1/SPORTS |date=2009-08-13 }}," ''The Journal News'' (Lower Hudson), August 10, 2009. Bryan is the only passenger of Schuler's vehicle to survive, suffering from broken bones and severe [[head trauma]]. He remained hospitalized before returning home in early October.Lysiak, Matthew and Gaskell, Stephanie. [http://www.nydailynews.com/news/ny_crime/2009/10/08/2009-10-08_sole_survivor_of_taconic_parkway_crash_5yearold_bryan_schuler_is_home_from_hospi.html "Sole Survivor of Taconic Parkway Crash, 5-Year-Old Bryan Schuler, is Home from Hospital]." ''[[New York Daily News]]'', 2009-10-08. Two men who witnessed the accident and smoke rising out of the van ran to assist the occupants. After removing Schuler from the van, the two men saw a large, broken [[Absolut Vodka]] bottle by the driver's side. The men tried to pull the girls out of the van, and noted that they had no pulse. Because the children possibly were not seat belted in and thrown together, the men did not even notice Bryan stuck under another child. Bryan was the only survivor of the accident. == Intoxication levels == The investigation of the collision drew nationwide attention, as Schuler's husband strongly disagreed with the conclusion that she was heavily [[alcohol intoxication|intoxicated]] at the time of the crash. A [[toxicology]] report released on August 4 by [[Westchester County]] [[medical examiner]]s found that Schuler had a [[blood-alcohol content]] (BAC) of 0.19%, with approximately six grams of alcohol in her stomach that had not yet been absorbed into her blood.Ferran, Lee. [http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/story?id=8249454&page=1 "Diane Schuler, Wrong-Way Highway Driver Who Killed 8, Had 10 Drinks, Was High]." ''[[ABC News]]'', 2009-08-04. Accessed 2009-09-16. [https://www.webcitation.org/5jt9SqSe8?url=http://abcnews.go.com/GMA/story?id%3D8249454%26page%3D1 Archived] 2009-09-18.Welch, William M. [https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2009-08-12-wrongway-mom_N.htm "All Reported Normal Before Woman's Fatal Wrong-Way Drive]." ''[[USA Today]]'', 2009-08-13.Fitz-Gibbon, Jorge and Shawn Cohen. [https://www.usatoday.com/news/nation/2009-08-06-ny-wrong-way-crash_N.htm "Husband: Wrong-way Driver Didn't Drink."] [[USA Today]], 2009-08-06. The legal BAC limit for Driving While Intoxicated in New York State is 0.08%. The report also said that Schuler had high levels of [[THC]], the active ingredient in [[marijuana]], in her system.Amon, Michael. [http://www.newsday.com/long-island/nassau/me-schuler-retests-will-show-lower-alcohol-content-1.1431224 "ME: Schuler retests will show lower alcohol content."] [[Newsday]], 2009-09-08. She could have smoked marijuana as recently as fifteen minutes before the accident. In an August 8 press conference, Daniel Schuler and his attorney Dominic Barbara initially denied that Diane did drugs or was drinking that weekend at the lake since several children were with them. Schuler then changed the story and consistently denied that his wife ever "drank to excess" or could have been drunk while driving that day.[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/08/07/earlyshow/main5223923.shtml "Wrong-Way Crash: "Diane Would Not Do This]." ''[[CBS News]]'', 2009-08-07.Ali, Aman. [http://www.lohud.com/article/20090903/NEWS02/909030366/ "Victims' Families Express Revulsion at Schuler's TV Appearance]." ''The Journal News'' (Lower Hudson), 2009-09-03. Accessed 2009-09-16. [https://www.webcitation.org/5jt9ToKEE?url=http://www.lohud.com/article/20090903/NEWS02/909030366/ Archived] 2009-09-18. When [[Larry King]] and [[Oprah Winfrey]] asked Daniel about the vodka in the van, Daniel claimed that they always kept an old bottle in their camper. He further stated that Diane did all the packing for the camping trip, so she must have moved the bottle into the van. Daniel eventually admitted that he and his wife had been drinking during the camping trip, but denied that Diane had anything to drink on the day preceding the crash.Millman, Jennifer. [http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local-beat/Taconic-Mom-Drank-But-Was-No-Drunk-Hubby-Changes-Story-69420057.html "Taconic Mom Drank But Was No Drunk: Hubby Changes Story]." ''NBC New York'', 2009-11-07.O'Connor, Anahad and Schweber, Nate. [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/11/07/nyregion/07taconic.html "Driver Said to Have Used Marijuana Regularly]." ''The New York Times'', 2009-11-06. The campground co-owner (who knew the Schulers well) saw them off at approximately {{nowrap|9 a.m.}} that morning, and stated that Diane appeared sober. The gas station employee whom Schuler asked for [[Tylenol (brand)|Tylenol]] at around {{nowrap|11 a.m.}} also said, "[I knew] for a fact [that] she wasn't drunk when she came into the station."Lysiak, Matthew. [http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2009/08/15/2009-08-15_family_of_victims_in_deadly_taconic_crash_support_gov_patersons_plan_to_toughen_.html "Family of Victims in Deadly Taconic crash Support Gov. Paterson's Plan to Toughen DWI Laws]." ''[[New York Daily News]]'', 2009-08-14. Accessed 2009-09-16. [https://www.webcitation.org/5jt9UF6li?url=http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2009/08/15/2009-08-15_family_of_victims_in_deadly_taconic_crash_support_gov_patersons_plan_to_toughen_.html Archived] 2009-09-18. According to Tom Ruskin (an investigator supposedly hired by Daniel for $30,000), none of the McDonald's employees saw anything in Schuler's behavior to suggest that she was intoxicated. In fact, she was observed carrying on an extended conversation while ordering her food and orange juice.Lysiak, Matthew and Siemaszko, Corky. [http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2009/11/19/2009-11-19_death_driver_diane_schuler_was_sober_in_mcdonalds_before_crash_says_family_inves.html "Death Driver Diane Schuler Was Sober in McDonald's Before Crash, Says Family Investigator]." ''New York Daily News'', 2009-11-19. Ruskin told reporters in September that he had interviewed relatives, none of whom had ever seen her in a drunken state.Melas, Chloe. [http://www.cnn.com/2009/US/08/30/new.york.crash/index.html "Family: No Signs of Long-Term Drinking in Driver in Fatal Crash]." ''[[CNN]]'', 2009-09-01.[http://www.nypost.com/p/news/regional/autopsy_wrong_way_crash_driver_not_TWJ8u4rJEwFfzGcKAd2RaP "Autopsy: Wrong-Way Crash Driver Not an Alcoholic]." ''[[New York Post]]'', 2009-09-02. Ruskin also pointed to [[autopsy]] results that showed an absence of organ damage often found in [[alcoholic]]s, although an uninvolved medical examiner said such results do not rule out alcoholism.Amon, Michael. [http://www.newsday.com/long-island/suffolk/expert-diane-schuler-should-have-had-hair-drug-test-1.1413988 "Expert: Diane Schuler Should Have Had Hair Drug Test]." ''[[Newsday]]'', 2009-09-01. Schuler relatives have also disputed that Diane was known to drink heavily or irresponsibly.Crowley, Kieran and Ginger Adams Otis. [http://www.nypost.com/seven/08142009/news/regionalnews/crash_ma_was_a_toker_184512.htm "Crash Ma Was a Toker]." ''[[New York Post]]'', 2009-08-17. Daniel Schuler denied that his wife did drugs, but told investigators that his wife smoked marijuana only "occasionally," and the family told ''[[People (magazine)|People]]'' magazine that she used it to relieve [[insomnia]]. Although Daniel Schuler was an officer in the Public Security Unit of the [[Nassau County Police Department]], he was not required to report his wife's drug use as he is a civilian.[http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/s/diane_schuler/index.html New York Times Topics: Diane Schuler],''[[The New York Times]]'', 2009-08-06. In November, it was reported that Schuler's sister-in-law had made a statement to police that she actually smoked marijuana on a regular basis. Daniel Schuler and attorney Barbara believed that Schuler drove erratically due to a medical issue, such as a [[stroke]]. According to Barbara, Schuler was [[obese]] for much of her life and suffered from [[diabetes]], although additional sources cite Schuler as only having had [[gestational diabetes]], a temporary condition related to a prior [[pregnancy]], rather than a chronic condition. Barbara has also mentioned an [[abscess]] that had persisted in her mouth for seven weeks before her death, and a lump in her leg, about which he said, "[It] might have been an [[embolism]]". The results of an [[autopsy]] conducted by a Westchester County medical examiner one day after the accident found that Schuler had not suffered a stroke, [[aneurysm]], or [[heart attack]].Amon, Michael. [http://www.newsday.com/long-island/nassau/authorities-autopsy-offers-no-explanation-for-crash-1.1332105 "Authorities: Autopsy Offers No Explanation for Crash]." ''[[Newsday]]'', 2009-07-28. In September, New York's top forensic pathologist said that a [[hair test]] should have been done to determine Schuler's drug history. Daniel Schuler and his lawyer announced plans to [[exhumation|exhume]] the body to perform the hair test and other examinations; experts said that this was unlikely to produce any new information of value since tests from two separate labs came up with exactly the same conclusion. Schuler also intended to re-test the fluid samples taken during the autopsy. The Westchester County medical examiner's office, which performed the autopsy, said that the degradation of the fluids over time was likely to result in lowered alcohol and THC readings; however, several toxicology experts said that the results should be similar to the previous test if the fluid samples had been properly stored. On November 7, Ruskin announced that the Schuler family had raised the money to retest Schuler's tissue samples and that the retesting would take place soon. In July 2010, it was reported that Daniel Schuler had accepted a $100,000 offer from a film company, Moxie Firecracker Films, to record his wife's exhumation for an [[HBO]] documentary. The money would reportedly be placed in trust for son Bryan.Lysiak, Matthew, et al. [http://www.nydailynews.com/ny_local/2010/07/27/2010-07-27_1_yr_after_taconic_2_families_battle_on.html "Families Fight over Planned HBO Film of Taconic Death Driver Diane Schuler on Anniversary of Tragedy]." ''[[New York Daily News]]'', 2010-07-27. Daniel Schuler's persistence in disputing his wife's intoxication and denying her drug use has been condemned by relatives of the three TrailBlazer victims.Celizic, Mike. [http://today.msnbc.msn.com/id/32688902/ns/today-today_people/ "Family of Wrong-Way Driver’s Victims Fires Back]." ''[[MSNBC]]'', 2009-09-04.{{cite web|last=Zmudzien|first=Redmond|title=Bastardi Jr. Says HBO Documentary was a "Farce"|url=http://tarrytown.dailyvoice.com/neighbors/bastardi-jr-says-hbo-documentary-was-farce|publisher=The Tarrytown Daily Voice}} When Schuler appeared on [[CNN]]'s ''[[Larry King Live]]'' to demand more testing of his wife's remains, Longo's brother Joseph issued a statement saying in part, "I want Daniel Schuler to know that he keeps inflicting more pain on all concerned once again [by] going to the media to try [to] paint a picture of a perfect wife and mother." Bastardi's daughters appeared with their lawyer on [[NBC]]'s ''[[Today (NBC program)|Today]]'', during which they questioned Daniel's culpability in [[enabling]] his wife's substance abuse and called for him to undergo drug testing himself. "It makes me angry that he keeps denying it," said Margaret Nicotina, Bastardi's daughter. "Every time he does it, he brings it back for us. I just wish that he would just admit that she was drunk. Maybe if he knows what happened that morning, if they argued or anything, that would be the truth. He wants the truth. So do we." Their lawyer called Daniel Schuler's position totally outrageous, an insult to the intelligence of the American public, and a [[hoax]]. Ruskin said on ''[[The Oprah Winfrey Show]]'' in October 2009 that Daniel Schuler had avoided media appearances since ''Larry King Live'' out of respect to the Bastardi family. In June 2010, the [[New York State Police]] issued its final report on the accident following eleven months of analysis. The report upheld the previous toxicology findings that Schuler was highly intoxicated and had high levels of THC in her system at the time of the accident.Ferrete, Candice. [http://www.lohud.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=20106290374 "Taconic Tragedy: Schuler Was Going 85 MPH in Wrong Direction, Final Police Report Says]." ''The Journal News'' (Lower Hudson), 2010-06-29. ==Legal action== According to a Westchester County medical examiner, the crash was ruled a [[homicide]] soon after it occurred, because the victims were killed due to Schuler's negligent driving, regardless of toxicology findings. On August 18, Westchester County [[District Attorney]] [[Janet DiFiore]] said that no charges would be filed in the incident, because Schuler was the only person responsible for the deaths. "Diane Schuler died in the crash and the charges died with her," DiFiore said.[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2009/08/18/national/main5250019.shtml?source=related_story "No Charges in Fatal Wrong-way Crash."] [[CBS News]], 2009-08-18. In October 2009, DiFiore faced accusations from Dan Schorr (a [[Republican Party (U.S.)|Republican]] challenger for her office) that she had mishandled the Schuler case. An attorney for the Bastardi family also alleged that DiFiore had mishandled the case. Both parties said that DiFiore should have initiated a [[grand jury]] investigation into the incident. In response to Schorr's comments, DiFiore responded, "Is he suggesting that there was criminal evidence of a crime committed by someone and we wouldn't pursue it? That's just silly."Aiello, Tony. [http://wcbstv.com/topstories/janet.difiore.dan.2.1239470.html "Challenger Pokes Holes In Westchester DA's Record]{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ''WCBS'', 2009-10-09. DiFiore won re-election in November with 53 percent of the vote to Schorr's 36 percent.Bandler, Jonathan. [http://www.lohud.com/article/20091105/NEWS02/911050359/DiFiore-pleased-with-easy-win--Schorr-proud-of-campaign "DiFiore Pleased with Easy Win, Schorr Proud of Campaign]." ''The Journal News'' (Lower Hudson), 2009-11-05. The Bastardi family said that if DiFiore did not convene a grand jury, they would seek support in the matter from the state attorney general and the governor.Ali, Aman. [http://www.lohud.com/article/20091101/NEWS02/911010402/-1/newsfront/Updated--Victims--family-wants-DA-to-investigate-Schuler-case "Updated: Victims' Family Wants DA to Investigate Schuler Case]." ''The Journal News'' (Lower Hudson), 2009-11-01. Following a request from the Bastardi family that an administrator be appointed for Schuler's estate so that a lawsuit could be filed, Daniel Schuler officially declined the role in November 2009, leaving it to a county-court judge to appoint a public administrator.Amon, Michael. [http://www.newsday.com/long-island/nassau/court-may-name-executor-of-diane-schuler-s-estate-1.1542543 "Court May Name Executor of Diane Schuler's Estate]." ''Newsday'', 2009-10-22.Ali, Aman. [http://www.lohud.com/article/20091118/NEWS02/911180325/-1/sports/Judge-to-appoint-administrator-for-Diane-Schuler%E2%80%99-s-estate "Judge to Appoint Administrator for Diane Schuler’s Estate]." ''The Journal News'' (Lower Hudson), 2009-11-18. On December 10, the Bastardi family filed suit against Diane Schuler and her brother, Warren Hance, seeking unspecified damages for wanton, willful, and reckless conduct. According to the family's lawyers, they were required by state law to include Hance in the suit because he was the owner of the van that Schuler was driving.Zraick, Karen. [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/12/11/nyregion/11taconic.html?_r=1 "Suit Filed in Wrong-Way Crash That Killed 8 on Taconic]." ''The New York Times'', 2009-12-10. In July 2011, Jackie Hance, who lost her three daughters in the accident, filed suit against her brother-in-law, Daniel Schuler.{{cite web|last=Michelin|first=Robert|title=Mother of Girls in Taconic Accident Files Suit|url=http://tarrytown.dailyvoice.com/news/mother-girls-taconic-accident-files-suit|publisher=The Tarrytown Daily Voice|accessdate=5 July 2012}} The suit claims that the three deceased Hance girls suffered terror, fear of impending death, extreme horror, fright, and mental anguish. On July 26, 2011, the day after the premiere of HBO's ''[[There's Something Wrong with Aunt Diane]]'', and on the second anniversary of the crash, Daniel announced that he is suing the State of New York for not "keeping the road safe" and his brother-in-law Warren Hance for being the owner of the minivan that Diane was driving.{{cite web|last=Michelin|first=Robert|title=Husband of Wrong Way Driver Sues State, In-Laws|url=http://briarcliff.dailyvoice.com/news/husband-wrong-way-driver-sues-state-laws|publisher=The Briarcliff Daily Voice}} By July 2014, all lawsuits by all parties were either settled or dropped. The judge sealed all the settlements. ==Child Passenger Protection Act== In August 2009, New York [[Governor of New York|Governor]] [[David Paterson]] proposed the [[Leandra's Law|Child Passenger Protection Act]], which would make it a [[felony]] to drive while intoxicated if a passenger under the age of 16 is in a vehicle. The proposal became known as [[Leandra's Law]], following the October 2009 death of 11-year-old Leandra Rosado, a passenger in a vehicle whose driver was drunk.Blain, Glenn. [http://www.nydailynews.com/news/2009/10/31/2009-10-31_gop_senator_fuschillo_demands_action_on_leandras_law.html "GOP Senator Fuschillo Demands Action, Tougher Laws for Drunken Driving: 'Leandra's Law].'" New York Daily News, 2009-10-31. The Child Passenger Protection Act was signed into New York law on November 18, 2009.Robinson, Cheryl. [http://www.cnn.com/2009/CRIME/11/19/new.york.dwi.law/ "New York Toughens Drunken Driving Law]." CNN, 2009-11-19. == Media == In September 2009, the syndicated talk show ''[[Dr. Phil (TV series)|Dr. Phil]]'' broadcast an episode about drunk-driving moms that focused heavily on Schuler and the crash.{{cite web|url=http://www.drphil.com/shows/show/1316|title=Dr. Phil.com - Shows - Drunk Driving Moms|work=drphil.com}} The next month, Oprah Winfrey devoted an episode of her show to the crash, interviewing Schuler's private investigator Tom Ruskin via [[Skype]], with Winfrey responding incredulously to several of his claims.Ali, Aman. [http://www.lohud.com/article/2009910290398 "Victims' Families Angered by Schuler Claims]." ''The Journal News'' (Lower Hudson), 2009-10-29.Feldman, Emily. [http://www.nbcnewyork.com/news/local-beat/Oprah-Challenges-Taconic-Crash-Investigator-on-Show-66925057.html "Oprah Challenges Taconic Crash Investigator on Show]." ''NBC New York'', 2009-10-28. The ''[[Law & Order]]'' episode "Doped," which first aired in November 2009, centers on a crash extremely similar to the Taconic Parkway incident. The fictionalized version features a woman who speeds down the [[West Side Highway]] in the wrong direction before crashing and killing herself, her daughter and her two nieces, and another family in another car.Melillo, Amanda. [http://www.nypost.com/p/entertainment/tv/taken_from_the_taconic_VVDzU4dLDlyfYwJp5UNrxN "Taken from the Taconic]." ''New York Post'', 2009-11-06. Bastardi relatives reacted with anger upon hearing that the NBC show would be basing an episode on the real-life tragedy.Crowley, Kieran. [http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/taconic_van_wreck_kin_blast_law_w95mivmnl6peFV6zTDG1JO "Taconic Van-Wreck Kin Blast ''Law & Order'' Copy Episode."] ''New York Post'', 2009-10-20. ''There's Something Wrong with Aunt Diane'', directed by [[Liz Garbus]] for [[HBO#Documentaries|HBO Documentaries]], establishes a timeline of events prior to the accident. The documentary suggests that Schuler could have been suffering from severe pain caused by a [[tooth abscess]] during the drive home, causing her to look for painkillers at the gas station and [[Self-medication|self-medicate]] with drugs and alcohol. The pain of the abscess, combined with vodka and marijuana, could have put her in a temporary state of [[delirium]] that triggered her fatal behavior.HBO, [http://www.hbo.com/documentaries/theres-something-wrong-with-aunt-diane/index.html#/documentaries/theres-something-wrong-with-aunt-diane/interview/liz-garbus.html ''There's something wrong with Aunt Diane'' - Interview with Liz Garbus] In the documentary, Daniel Schuler and attorney Barbara claim they gave investigator Ruskin $30,000 to conduct an independent investigation and to re-test samples. Throughout the documentary, Jay Schuler, Diane Schuler's sister-in-law, and husband Daniel Schuler claim that Ruskin was not returning their phone calls for nine months. At the end of the documentary, Ruskin states that he had called her months ago with the results, and that she refused to pick up her phone. She is seen claiming that "she was told not to pick up" and "that she didn't understand any of it." Ruskin then informs her that his tests corroborated the previous tests; that Diane Schuler was highly intoxicated from alcohol and marijuana. Schuler's family persisted in refusing to accept the test results. Jackie Hance wrote a book called ''I'll See You Again'' in which the tragedy is revisited, focusing on her initial grief and later reemergence into life.Time - Health & Family, [http://healthland.time.com/2013/05/12/ill-see-you-again/ I'll see you again], Alexandra Sifferlin, May 12, 2013. [[Stephen King]]'s short story "[[Herman Wouk is Still Alive]]" in ''Bazaar of Bad Dreams'' (2015) is, according to King, a fictional attempt to find answers to questions about what led to the crash and "perhaps to obtain some sort of closure." ==The Hance Family Foundation== Jackie and Warren Hance formed a foundation, the Hance Family Foundation, whose main purpose is to honor the lives of their three daughters by ensuring healthy, happy, and safe children through innovative self-esteem educational programming. The foundation's central project is Beautiful Me, a self-esteem program designed to educate girls by promoting appreciation for their genuine qualities, accurate self-awareness, and the satisfaction of helping others.{{cite web|url=http://www.hancefamilyfoundation.org/|title=Home - Hance Family Foundation|work=Hance Family Foundation}} ==See also== {{portal|2000s|Death|Disasters|Hudson Valley|Transport}} *[[List of traffic collisions (2000–present)]] *[[Carrollton bus collision]], similar 1988 accident in Kentucky involving intoxicated driver going the wrong way on a divided highway; killed 27. *[[Valhalla train crash]], 2015 [[grade crossing]] accident, also in town of Mount Pleasant and involving counterintuitive, high-risk behavior by SUV driver who was among the six fatalities. ==References== {{Reflist|2}} == External links == * [http://www.autopsyfiles.org/reports/policereport/schuler,%20diane_police_report.pdf Police report] * [http://www.autopsyfiles.org/reports/Other/schuler,%20diane_report.pdf Autopsy Report of Diane Schuler] * [https://www.nytimes.com/imagepages/2009/07/27/nyregion/28crashmap.ready.html Anatomy of a Tragic Accident] Overhead photos of the crash scene, and route map (''The New York Times'') * [https://maps.google.com/maps?f=q&source=s_q&hl=en&q=Taconic+State+Pkwy,+New+York&sll=37.0625,-95.677068&sspn=40.052282,54.052734&ie=UTF8&cd=1&geocode=FXSsdQIdEsiZ-w&split=0&ll=41.141708,-73.815143&spn=0.009324,0.013196&t=h&z=16 Map of accident] Road map of accident location (maps.google.com) * [http://www.myfoxny.com/generic/news/Taconic_Crash_911_Audio 911 calls by family and motorists] * {{findagrave|83705275}} * [http://www.timeforkids.com/news/what-makes-you-beautiful/92896 What Makes You Beautiful], a program of the Hance Family Foundation {{coord|41.119729|-73.807051|format=dms|type:event|display=title}} [[Category:Driving under the influence|Taconic State Parkway crash 2009]] [[Category:Mount Pleasant, New York|Taconic State Parkway crash 2009]] [[Category:Road incidents in the United States|Taconic State Parkway crash 2009]] [[Category:2009 road incidents|Taconic State Parkway crash]] [[Category:2009 in New York (state)|Taconic State Parkway crash]] [[Category:Transportation disasters in New York (state)]] [[Category:July 2009 events|Taconic State Parkway crash]]

{{Use Australian English|date=March 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2013}} {{Infobox event | title = <!-- Title to display, if other than page name --> | image = Alan Jones cropped.jpg | image_size = 280px | caption = [[Alan Jones (radio broadcaster)|Jones]], pictured in 2011 | date = {{start date|2012|09|23|df=y}} | time = | venue = [[Sydney University Liberal Club]] | place = | coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LON|region:XXXX_type:event|display=inline,title}} --> | first reporter = Jonathan Marshall, via [[News Limited]] agencies<ref name=privacy/> | participants = {{plainlist| *[[Alan Jones (radio broadcaster)|Alan Jones]] *Simon Berger *[[Julia Gillard]] (collateral damage) *[[Macquarie Radio Network]] (collateral damage)}} | outcome = More than 80{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} companies withdrew advertising from the Alan Jones Show;<ref name="sdaj"/><ref name=austHCF/> reportedly cost [[2GB]] up to {{AUD}}80,000 per day.<ref name="smh1"/> [[Macquarie Radio Network|Macquarie Radio]] estimated the boycott cost between {{AUD}}1{{spaced endash}}1.5 million; some advertisers said they will never return.<ref name=radioinfosponsors/> | notes = }} The '''Alan Jones''' "'''died of shame'''" '''controversy''' originated from a speech made by Australian radio broadcaster [[Alan Jones (radio broadcaster)|Alan Jones]] in September 2012, in which Jones suggested that then-Australian Prime Minister [[Julia Gillard]]'s late father, John, "died of shame" over his daughter telling lies.
==Background== On 23 September 2012, [[Sydney University Liberal Club]] hosted its annual president's dinner with a keynote address by Sydney radio presenter Alan Jones. In his address, Jones was cited as saying, in reference to Prime Minister [[Julia Gillard]]'s recently deceased father, John Gillard, "The old man recently died a few weeks ago of shame. To think that he had a daughter who told lies every time she stood for parliament".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/julia-gillards-father-died-of-shame-alan-jones/story-e6frg6n6-1226484516814|title=Julia Gillard's father died of shame: Alan Jones|work=The Australian|date=28 September 2012|accessdate=2 October 2012|others = Audio recording}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Aston, Heath|url=http://www.theage.com.au/opinion/political-news/gillards-father-died-of-shame-alan-jones-20120929-26soa.html|title=Alan Jones says Julia Gillard's father died of shame|work=The Age|date=29 September 2012|accessdate=2 October 2012|location=Melbourne}}</ref> At the same event, the Club was auctioning a jacket made from [[chaff]] bags, autographed by Alan Jones, a reference to his previous comments on radio that Julia Gillard should be "put into a chaff bag and thrown into the sea".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/national/jones-says-gillards-dad-died-of-shame/story-fncynkc6-1226484128451|title=Alan Jones apologises for speech that claimed PM's father 'died of shame'|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=30 September 2012|accessdate=4 October 2012}}</ref>
Following this speech being made public by the media on 29 September 2012,<ref>{{cite news|title=Julia Gillard's father died of shame: Alan Jones|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/julia-gillards-father-died-of-shame-alan-jones/story-e6frg6n6-1226484516814|accessdate=7 April 2013|newspaper=The Australian|date=29 September 2012}}</ref> there were calls for [[2GB]] to dismiss Jones. Jones' speech was secretly recorded by a [[News Limited]] journalist.<ref name=privacy>{{cite news|title=Journalist says no Jones privacy breach|url=http://www.smh.com.au/opinion/political-news/journalist-says-no-jones-privacy-breach-20121001-26unk.html|accessdate=2 October 2012|newspaper=The Sydney Morning Herald|date=1 October 2012|agency=[[Australian Associated Press|AAP]]}}</ref> After the remarks were condemned across social media and the Australian media, Jones held a press conference and apologised. Jones also attempted to contact the Prime Minister to offer a personal apology, but was told she would not be returning his call. One academic linked the public reaction to the "bigger political and media context", citing the [[Leveson Inquiry]] in Britain, saying that it shows the "dark side of media power, including bullying by media owners and powerful media individuals who lobby politicians, demand favours, use their outlets as a bully pulpit and to seek revenge when they don't get their way."<ref>{{cite news|last=Young|first=Sally|title=Shock for the shock jock|url=http://m.smh.com.au/opinion/shock-for-the-shock-jock-20121001-26vgp.html|accessdate=2 October 2012|newspaper=National Times|date=2 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/alan-jones-apologises-to-prime-minister-julia-gillard-over-comments/story-fn59niix-1226484697310//Default.aspx|title=Alan Jones apologises to prime minister Julia Gillard over comments|date=29 September 2012|work=The Australian|accessdate=1 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/national/private-dinner-with-alan-jones-was-open-to-anyone/story-fndo317g-1226484904859//Default.aspx|title='Private' dinner with Alan Jones was open to anyone|date=29 September 2012|work=Herald Sun|accessdate=1 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/opinion/political-news/calls-mount-for-alan-jones-to-be-sacked-20121001-26ufs.html//Default.aspx |title=Calls mount for Alan Jones to be sacked |date=29 September 2012 |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |accessdate=1 October 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121003235247/http://www.smh.com.au/opinion/political-news/calls-mount-for-alan-jones-to-be-sacked-20121001-26ufs.html |archivedate=3 October 2012 |df=dmy }} </ref>
Following the controversy over the comments made by Jones, on 7 October his employer, [[Macquarie Radio Network]], announced that it would suspend all advertising on the Alan Jones breakfast show on 2GB to protect its advertisers from pressure being applied through social [[media activism]].<ref>{{cite news|title=2GB drop all advertising on Jones Show|publisher=radiotoday.com.au|url=http://www.radiotoday.com.au/news/whats-new/1358-2gb-drop-all-advertising-on-jones-show.html|accessdate=7 October 2012|website=www.radiotoday.com.au|date=7 October 2012}}</ref>
Jones returned to the airwaves on 8 October 2012 without advertising.<ref>{{cite news|title=Ad-free Alan Jones back on air|url=http://www.abc.net.au/am/content/2012/s3605648.htm|publisher=[[ABC Radio (Australia)|ABC Radio]]|location=Australia|work=[[AM (ABC Radio)|AM]]|accessdate=7 April 2013}}</ref>
Advertising resumed on the Jones' show on 16 October 2012 without many major advertisers.<ref>{{cite news|title=Advertisers return today to Jones show|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/media/advertisers-return-today-to-jones-show/story-e6frg996-1226496677169|accessdate=7 April 2013|newspaper=The Australian|date=16 October 2012}}</ref>
==Reaction== Prime Minister Julia Gillard said she would not comment on Jones's remarks, but instead thanked the Australian people for the "outpouring of support" that she and her family had received following the death of her father. When asked if she would appear on Jones's radio program she said, "No, I would not. I haven't spoken to Mr Jones and I don't intend to."<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/news/national/prime-minister-julia-gillard-addresses-community-cabinet-in-launceston/story-fndo1uez-1226487190369 |title=Prime Minister Julia Gillard won't comment on Alan Jones's comments during press conference in Launceston |work=The Courier-Mail |date=3 October 2012 |accessdate=27 October 2012}}</ref>
Former Prime Minister [[Kevin Rudd]] described the comments as the "lowest of the low" and said he would be boycotting Jones's program.<ref name="grtod">{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-10-03/gillard-refuses-to-be-drawn-on-jones-controversy/4293014|title=Gillard refuses to be drawn on Jones controversy|author=Cullen, Simon|accessdate=8 October 2012|date=3 October 2012|work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|location=Australia}}</ref>
Foreign Minister [[Bob Carr]] said Jones's comments were indecent and the public reaction was justifiable. Senator Carr further said "I cannot believe that it is helpful for a commercial enterprise to live with the brand 'hate radio'. And I just think the vehemence and the virulence of the message that comes out of the radio station is a very unhelpful thing for Australia.”<ref>{{cite news|title=Jones comment indecent|url=http://www.abc.net.au/lateline/content/2012/s3603332.htm|work=[[Lateline]]|publisher=ABC TV|quote=''I think it was quite indecent and I think the public reaction is justifiable, but I think the point ought to be made: the people who cheered it are activists in the Liberal Party and the sort of people who'd be around Tony Abbott and his ministers were he to win the next election and the challenge is for Tony Abbott to tear up his links with such generators of hatred and virulence.''|date=3 October 2012 |accessdate=7 April 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Backlash a warning for Alan Jones: Bob Carr|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/national/backlash-a-warning-for-jonescarr/story-fncynkc6-1226487770144|agency=AAP|date=4 October 2014|accessdate=|work=Herald Sun}}</ref>
Opposition member [[Malcolm Turnbull]] said Jones's remarks were "cruel and offensive" and that "he should apologise to the PM and her family".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/national/jones-says-gillards-dad-died-of-shame/story-fncynjr2-1226484669276 |title=The PM's dad died of shame: Alan Jones under fire after cruel and offensive attack on Gillard |newspaper=news.com.au |date=30 September 2012 |accessdate=2012-10-27}}</ref> He described the power of the social media campaign that caused sponsors to act as "both inspiring and horrifying"<ref>{{cite news|title=Jones campaign 'inspiring, horrifying', says Malcolm Turnbull|url=http://www.news.com.au/technology/jones-campaign-inspiring-horrifying-says-malcolm-turnbull/story-e6frfro0-1226494256334|accessdate=7 April 2013|newspaper=news.com.au|date=12 October 2012}}</ref> and said Jones has got "a dose of his own medicine". Turnbull further said that Jones had not been the victim of [[cyberbullying]] as Jones claimed but new media had allowed thousands of Australians to speak up "unedited and unmediated".<ref>{{cite news|date=9 October 2012 |url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/1699741/Turnbull-Jones-gets-dose-of-own-medicine |archive-url=https://archive.is/20121230223201/http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/1699741/Turnbull-Jones-gets-dose-of-own-medicine |dead-url=yes |archive-date=30 December 2012 |title=Turnbull: Jones gets dose of own medicine |work=[[SBS News]] |location=Australia |accessdate=10 October 2012 }}</ref>
Opposition Leader [[Tony Abbott]] described Jones's comments as "wrong and offensive".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/national-affairs/i-wont-ignore-alan-joness-radio-audience-tony-abbott/story-fn59niix-1226486507321|work=The Australian|title=I won't ignore Alan Jones's radio audience: Tony Abbott|date=2 October 2012}}</ref> However, he used the word 'shame' in parliament on 9 October, stating that due to the ongoing [[Peter Slipper#Sexual harassment and further expenses allegations|Peter Slipper affair]] the government "should already have died of shame".<ref>{{cite news|last=Pearson |first=Nick |title=Government should have died of shame: Abbott |url=http://news.ninemsn.com.au/national/8544976/government-should-have-died-of-shame-abbott |accessdate=9 October 2012 |date=9 October 2012 |agency=[[Ninemsn]] }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> Gillard [[Misogyny speech|responded]], publicly addressing this issue directly for the first time, criticising Abbott during parliamentary [[question time]] for "misogyny and sexism".<ref>{{cite news|title=Gillard labels Abbott a misogynist|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-10-09/julia-gillard-attacks-abbott-of-hypocrisy/4303634|accessdate=9 October 2012|date=9 October 2012|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|format=video}}</ref> Her speech was reported worldwide, going "viral" on social media outlets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://about.abc.net.au/2012/10/social-shift-sees-gillard-goes-viral/ |title=Social shift sees Gillard goes viral |publisher=About the ABC|accessdate=27 October 2012}}</ref>
Woolworths state government relations manager Simon Berger who was the master of ceremonies at the function where Jones spoke, and who had donated the chaff bag jacket auctioned,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/opinion/political-news/chaff-bag-jacket-donated-by-woolworths-executive-20121001-26ufx.html |title=Chaff bag jacket donated by Woolworths executive |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |accessdate=27 October 2012}}</ref> resigned from his position as a result of this controversy.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-10-05/woolies-manager-quits-amid-alan-jones-row/4298598 |title=Woolies exec quits amid Alan Jones row|work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|location=Australia|publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |accessdate=27 October 2012}}</ref> Woolworths said "While Simon attended the function in a private capacity, he has acknowledged that it has directly affected his ability to carry out his role at Woolworths as a member of Corporate Affairs team."<ref>{{cite news|title=Jones scandal costs Woolworths executive Simon Berger his job|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/national/jones-scandal-costs-woolworths-executive-simon-berger-his-job/story-fncynkc6-1226489427381|date=5 October 2014|author=Farr, Malcolm|authorlink=Malcolm Farr|work=Herald Sun|accessdate=}}</ref>
===Regional radio stations=== By 17 October, three regional radio stations, Albury based [[2AY]], Deniliquin based station [[2QN]] and Darwin's [[Territory FM]] had stopped broadcasting Jones' show.<ref name="sdaj">{{cite news|url=http://www.brisbanetimes.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/sponsors-drop-alan-jones-after-attack-on-pm-20121001-26ugl.html|title=Sponsors drop Alan Jones after attack on PM|author1=Idato, Michael|author2=Quinn, Karl|accessdate=8 October 2012|date=1 October 2012|work=Brisbane Times|publisher=Fairfax Media}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=2AY dumps Alan Jones|url=http://www.bordermail.com.au/story/369017/2ay-dumps-alan-jones/?cs=53|accessdate=7 April 2013|newspaper=The Border Mail|date=2012-10-01}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Top End radio station banishes Alan Jones show|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-10-17/territory-fm-banishes-alan-jones-radio-show/4318826|accessdate=7 April 2013|newspaper=ABC NEWS|date=17 October 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Alan gets the boot - for good|url=http://www.ntnews.com.au/article/2012/10/17/314399_entertainment.html|accessdate=7 April 2013|newspaper=[[NT News]]|date=17 October 2012}}</ref>
===Sponsors=== More than 80{{citation needed|date=April 2013}} companies pulled out of advertising from the Alan Jones Show including [[Mercedes-Benz]] [[Hornsby, New South Wales|Hornsby]], [[Woolworths (supermarket)|Woolworths]], [[Freedom Furniture]], [[Lexus]] of [[Parramatta]],<ref name="sdaj"/> [[Coles Supermarkets|Coles]], [[ING Group|ING]], [[Bing Lee]], [[Mazda]], [[7-Eleven]], [[Sydney Symphony Orchestra]] and [[HCF Health Insurance]].<ref name=austHCF>{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/media/hcf-baulks-as-ad-aired-on-jones-show/story-e6frg996-1226504898329 | work=The Australian | title=HCF baulks as ad aired on Jones show|date=29 October 2012}}</ref> The pull out by advertisers was reported to cost 2GB up to $80,000 per day.<ref name="smh1">{{cite news|author=Quinn, Karl|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/alan-jones-80000aday-problem-20121002-26xb8.html|title=Alan Jones' $80,000-a-day problem |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=16 April 2012 |accessdate=27 October 2012}}</ref>
Mercedes Benz also withdrew Jones' [[Mercedes-Benz S-Class|Mercedes S-Class]] worth $250,000 which was part of the sponsorship deal.<ref name="ajlh">{{cite news|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/alan-jones-loses-his-merc/story-e6frg6n6-1226489835280|title=Alan Jones loses his Mercedes-Benz and Macquarie Radio Network suspends all ads over comments made about PM Julia Gillard's father|author1=Marshall, Jonathan|author2=Baker, Jordan|author3=Wood, Alicia|accessdate=8 October 2012|date=7 October 2012|newspaper=The Australian}}</ref><ref name="ajtt">{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-10-07/alan-jones-told-to-give-24250k-car-back/4299572|title=Alan Jones told to return $250k Mercedes|accessdate=8 October 2012|date=7 October 2012|work=[[ABC News (Australia)|ABC News]]|location=Australia}}</ref>
Macquarie Radio estimated the boycott cost the station between $1 million and $1.5 million, and some advertisers said they will never return.<ref name=radioinfosponsors>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.radioinfo.com.au/news/11711/tv-and-radio/sponsors-drop-alan-jones-after-attack-on-pm-20121001-26ugl.html|title=er $1 million lost from Alan Jones advertiser boycott|publisher=radioinfo |date=15 November 2012|accessdate=15 November 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|agency= Australian Associated Press |url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/alan-jones-costs-radio-network-over-1m-20121115-29eq2.html |title=Alan Jones costs radio network over $1m|work=The Sydney Morning Herald |date=15 November 2012 |accessdate=15 November 2012}}</ref>
=== Radio audience === In the [[Nielsen N.V.|Nielsen]] radio survey conducted between 29 July 2012 and 20 October 2012, Jones increased his share of total radio listeners, gaining an extra 0.5% of the market. Jones had 17.3 per cent of the audience for 2GB from 5.30am to 9am.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite news|author=Ellis, Scott|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/tv-and-radio/alan-jones-gained-listeners-amid-gillard-controversy-20121030-28gs4.html |title=Sydney radio ratings |work=The Sydney Morning Herald |accessdate=30 October 2012}}</ref><ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite news|url=http://www.news.com.au/breaking-news/national/backlash-fails-to-leave-dent-on-alan-jones/story-e6frfku9-1226506783911 |title=Backlash fails to leave dent on Alan Jones |publisher=News.com.au |accessdate=30 October 2012|date=30 October 2012}}</ref><ref name="heraldsun1">{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/national/alan-jones-scandal-a-ratings-winner/story-fndo317g-1226506674077|title=Alan Jones scandal a ratings winner|author=Keene, Neil|work=The Daily Telegraph|date=30 October 2012|accessdate=}}</ref>
The Nielsen radio survey conducted between 28 October 2012 and 23 February 2013 indicates the 2GB audience is 15.4 per cent for the 5.30am to 9.00am time slot.<ref>{{cite web|title=Survey #1 2013|url=http://www.nielsen.com/content/dam/corporate/au/en/surveys/2013/SydneySurvey1-2013.pdf|publisher=[[Nielsen N.V.|Nielsen]]|type=PDF|accessdate=7 April 2013}}</ref>

AMG |image_flag = |alt_flag = |symbol_type = |image_symbol = |alt_symbol = |symbol_width = |motto = |anthem = |text_symbol_type = |text_symbol = |image_map = |alt_map = |map_width = |map_caption = |org_type = Military occupation |membership_type = |membership = |admin_center_type = |admin_center = |official_languages = {{flatlist|{{unbulleted list |[[English language|English]] |[[Italian language|Italian]] |[[French language|French]] |[[German language|German]] |[[Japanese language|Japanese]]}}}} |leader_title1 = |leader_name1 = |established = |established_event1 = |established_date1 = |area_rank = |area_magnitude = |area_km2 = |area_sq_mi = |area_footnote = |percent_water = |population_estimate = |population_estimate_rank = |population_estimate_year = |population_density_km2 = |population_density_sq_mi = |population_density_rank = |GDP_PPP = |GDP_PPP_rank = |GDP_PPP_year = |GDP_PPP_per_capita = |GDP_PPP_per_capita_rank = |GDP_nominal = |GDP_nominal_rank = |GDP_nominal_year = |GDP_nominal_per_capita = |GDP_nominal_per_capita_rank = |Gini = |Gini_year = |Gini_category = |HDI = |HDI_rank = |HDI_year = |HDI_category = |currency = {{flatlist|{{unbulleted list |[[Allied Military Currency]] |[[AM-Lira]] |[[AM-Franc]] |[[Austrian schilling#Second schilling|AM-Schilling]] |[[AM-Mark]] |[[A yen]] |[[B yen]]}}}} |currency_code = |time_zone = |utc_offset = }} [[File:1948 Allied Military Government franchise stamp.jpg|200px|thumb|A [[franchise stamp]] issued by the Allied Military Government (AMG) in 1948 to exempt travellers from fees when crossing borders."Germany: Allied Military Government Travel Permits 1947-51" by Theo J.F. Schalke in [[Revenue Society|The Revenue Journal]], Vol. XXII, No. 3, December 2011, pp. 129-139.]] [[File:Allied Military Government stamps.jpg|200px|thumb|Three [[revenue stamp]]s of the AMG from 1950 and 1951.]] [[File:Belgium 2 francs 1944 reverse.jpg|220px|thumb|The [[1944 Belgian 2 Franc coin|1944 Belgian 2 francs]]. These coins were minted at the [[Philadelphia Mint]] in the United States, due to the German occupation of Belgium, and circulated during the American liberation.]] The '''Allied Military Government for Occupied Territories''' (originally abbreviated '''AMGOT''', later '''AMG''') was the form of military rule administered by Allied forces during and after [[World War II]] within European territories they occupied. == Notable AMGOT == This form of controlled government was implemented in the states of [[Germany]], [[Italy]],[http://jcgi.pathfinder.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,802871,00.html Friendly Isle], Time, July 26, 1943 [[Austria]] and [[Japan]], amongst others. === Opposition of France === [[Image:Billet drapeau de 100 francs recto.jpg|200px|thumb|A [[dollar]]-like 100-[[franc]] note produced by the Americans and supplied in June 1944 following [[Operation Overlord|Operation "Overlord"]].]] US President [[Franklin Roosevelt]] insisted that an AMGOT should be implemented in France, but this was opposed by both [[Henry_L._Stimson|Henry Stimson]], the US Secretary of War, the [[John_J._McCloy|US Under-Secretary for War]], as well as Allied Europe Supreme Commander, General [[Dwight Eisenhower]], who had been strongly opposed to the imposition of AMGOT in North Africa. Eisenhower, unlike Roosevelt, wanted to cooperate with [[Charles de Gaulle]], and he secured a last-minute promise from Roosevelt on the eve of D-Day that the Allied officers would not act as military governors and would instead cooperate with the local authorities as the Allied forces liberated French territory{{citation needed|date=November 2018}}. De Gaulle would, however, later claim in his memoirs that he blocked AMGOT.Kim Munholland, Rock of Contention, Free French and Americans at War in New Caledonia 1940–1945, Berghahn Books, New York, Oxford, 2005, p. 190. The AMGOT would have been implemented in France after its liberation if not for the Free French establishing control of the country per the [[Provisional Government of the French Republic]] in the name of the [[Free French Forces]] and the united [[French Resistance]] ([[French Forces of the Interior|FFI]]) following the [[liberation of Paris]] by the French themselves instead of the Allies, in August 1944.[https://books.google.fr/books?id=QN9k6DW5uN0C&pg=PA68&dq=henri+giraud+roosevelt&hl=fr&sa=X&ei=2XXKVK3pF5XlauWngYAE&ved=0CD0Q6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=henri%20giraud%20roosevelt&f=false Charles L. Robertson, "When Roosevelt Planned to Govern France"] === Germany === {{Main|Allied Control Council}} Germany's control was notably divided amongst the powers of the [[Soviet Union]], the [[United States]], the [[United Kingdom]], and [[France]]. ===Italy=== ====Sicily==== After [[Operation Husky]], with the Allied Invasion of [[Sicily]] on July 10, 1943, the Allied Military Government was established with Staff Officer [[Francis Rodd, 2nd Baron Rennell]] and Civil Affairs officer colonel [[Charles Poletti]], until February 1944. ==== Free Territory of Trieste ==== The Allied Military Government of Zone A of the [[Free Territory of Trieste]] was a follow-on from the military government of occupied Italy. It was established upon implementation of the [[Treaty of Peace with Italy, 1947|Treaty of Peace with Italy, 15 September 1947]], which created the free territory divided into two zones. Zone A was administered by the United States and the United Kingdom. Zone B was administered by Yugoslavia. Military government ended when the free territory was divided between Italy and Yugoslavia, November 1954, under the provisions of the [[London Memorandum]], a memorandum of understanding among the United States, United Kingdom, Italy and Yugoslavia. == See also == * [[Allied Commission]] * ''[[A Bell for Adano]]'' is a [[1944 in literature|1944]] novel by [[John Hersey]] centered on the [[AMGOT]] control of the fictional Italian village of [[Adano]] based in the village of [[Licata]]. == References == {{reflist}} Trieste Revenue stamps listed in ''Italy Revenues" by J.Barefoot Ltd, York, 2013, {{ISBN|0-906845-73-4}}. == External links == * [http://www.infoplease.com/ce6/history/A0833170.html Infoplease-Military Government] * [http://users.skynet.be/jeeper/currency.html Allied Military Currency] {{DEFAULTSORT:Allied Military Government For Occupied Territories}} [[Category:Military occupation]] [[Category:Aftermath of World War II]]

page.title: Boys are stupid, throw rocks at them! controversy

revision.text:
{{pp-pc1}} [[Image:BoysAreStupid.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Cover of the ''Boys are stupid...'' book]] "'''Boys are stupid, throw rocks at them!'''" is a slogan on a [[T-shirt]] by [[Florida]] clothing company [[Todd Goldman|David and Goliath]] which in 2003 became the subject of a campaign by radio-host and [[Fathers' rights movement|fathers' rights activist]] Glenn Sacks on the grounds of [[misandry]] and the incitement of violence against children. This raised national attention and led to the removal of the shirts from several thousand retail outlets.<ref>{{cite news | first = D | last = Crary | url = http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2001847133_stupidboys30.html | title = 'Stores pull "Boys Are Stupid" merchandise' | work = [[The Seattle Times]] | date = 2004-01-30 | accessdate = 2009-05-17 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090125143238/http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/nationworld/2001847133_stupidboys30.html | archivedate = 2009-01-25 | df = }}</ref> Sacks' campaign was criticized as focusing on a trivial issue.
The publicity of the campaign increased sales of the shirt, which features the slogan printed next to a cartoon image of a boy running away from five stones flying in his direction, which was later used as the cover of a book which was also titled ''Boys are stupid, throw rocks at them!''.
==T-shirt== The T-shirt was designed by company founder [[Todd Goldman]], who started David and Goliath in 1999 with "Boys are Smelly" T-shirts. It now features clothes with a variety of slogans, such as "Boys tell lies, poke them in the eyes!" or "The stupid factory, where boys are made". "Boys are stupid ..." has evolved into a successful object for merchandise, which includes all types of clothes, mugs, key chains, posters and other items. In 2005, Goldman published a book with the same title.<ref>{{cite book |author=Goldman, Todd |authorlink= Todd Goldman|title=Boys Are Stupid, Throw Rocks at Them! |publisher=Workman Publishing Company |location= |year=2005 |pages= |isbn=0-7611-3593-6 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref>
==Reaction== [[Los Angeles]] based radio host and [[Father's rights|father's rights activist]] Glenn Sacks initiated a campaign against the T-shirts in 2003. He claimed that they were part of a general societal mood that stigmatizes and victimizes boys.<ref name="Final Update">{{cite web |last=Sacks |first=G |authorlink=Glenn Sacks |date=2004-03-04 |title=Final Update - Glenn Sacks campaign blog against "Boys are stupid..." |url=http://www.hisside.com/campaign_boys_are.htm |accessdate=2009-05-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090727093706/http://hisside.com/campaign_boys_are.htm |archivedate=2009-07-27 |df= }}</ref> The company says that the shirts are not meant to encourage violence.<ref name=Binks>{{cite news | first = G | last = Binks | title = The mean T-shirt: From the Stupid Factory | work = [[The National Post]] | date = 2004-05-29 }}</ref> According to Goldman, the controversy boosted sales of the T-shirt.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A17161-2004Feb29.html|publisher=[[Reuters]], via [[The Washington Post]]|date=February 29, 2004|accessdate=2014-04-10|title=Anti-Boy T-Shirts Get Boost from Boycott}}</ref>
Helen Grieco, executive director of the [[National Organization for Women]] stated "No, I don't think the shirts are cute. But I spend every day on life-and-death issues and don't have time for T-shirt campaigns." She went on to state that while she believed the US needed a men's rights movement, she didn't think Sacks should be the one doing it, calling him a "women-bashing, backlash shock-jock radio host." <ref>{{cite news | first = P | last = Cangelosi | title = Bashing boys is, like, not OK | url = http://www.csmonitor.com/2004/0331/p16s01-lihc.html | accessdate = 2009-05-19 | date = 2004-03-31 | publisher = [[The Christian Science Monitor]] }}</ref> Others, like ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' columnist Jane Ganahl ridiculed Sacks' efforts in an article saying, "shut up and get a life, already".<ref>{{cite news | first = J | last = Ganahl | url = http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2004/02/22/LVGPM53D151.DTL | title = Will you please shut up and get a life, already? Critics targeting anti-boy T-shirts must have something better to do than take political correctness to new depths of inanity| work = [[San Francisco Chronicle]] | date = 2004-02-22 | accessdate = 2009-05-19 }}</ref>
Glenn Sacks responded to criticism of the campaign, asserting that the criticism was dismissive of the feelings of boys and that the idea that boys should laugh at the joke at their expense creates a "[[double bind]]" for boys.<ref>{{cite news | first = G | last = Sacks | url = http://www.glennsacks.com/why_i_launched.htm | title = Why I Launched the Campaign Against "Boys are Stupid" Products | work = [[Los Angeles Daily News]] |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040213094947/http://www.glennsacks.com/why_i_launched.htm|archivedate=13 February 2004| date = 2004-02-04 }}</ref>
In Canada, the complaints by the [[Canadian Children's Rights Council]] resulted in numerous major retail chain stores stopping their sales of the merchandise.<ref name=Binks/> Other retailers who pulled the merchandise included [[The Bon Marché|Bon-Macy’s]], [[Tilly's]], and [[Claire’s]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/4099643/ns/us_news/t/retailerspull-boys-are-stupid-products/#.U0cGXVcbGmA|title=Retailers pull 'Boys are Stupid' products|date=2004-01-29|accessdate=2014-04-10|publisher=NBC News reprint of [[Associated Press]] article}}</ref>

[[File:Hogarth's Children's Party.PNG|thumb|right|''A Children's Party'' painted by [[William Hogarth]] in 1730]] A '''children's party''' or '''kids' party''' is a [[party]] for [[children]] such as a [[birthday party]] or [[tea party (social gathering)|tea party]]. Since medieval times, children have dressed specially for such occasions.<ref>{{citation |title=Children in Their Party Dress |author=Nora Villa |year=1996 |isbn=978-0-89676-202-2}}</ref>
[[File:Mall culture jakarta76.jpg|thumb|A magician entertaining children at a [[Wendy's]] restaurant in [[Jakarta]], Indonesia during a birthday party.]]
Children's birthday parties originated in Germany as ''kinderfeste''.<ref>{{citation |title=Encyclopedia of Recreation and Leisure in America |author=Gary S. Cross |page=104 |year=2004 |publisher=Charles Scribner's Sons |isbn=978-0-684-31266-8}}</ref>
Businesses that plan or arrange children's parties have become more common during the 2010s.<ref>Kavilanz, P. (2013, May 22). Startup ideas: 8 hot businesses you can start now. CNNMoney. Retrieved from http://money.cnn.com/gallery/smallbusiness/2013/05/22/startup-ideas/6.html</ref>
