The '''Pottery Barn rule''' is an American expression alluding to a policy of '''"you break it, you bought it"''' or '''"you break it, you buy it"''' or '''"you break it, you remake it"''', by which a retail store holds a customer responsible for damage done to merchandise on display. It generally "encourages customers to be more careful when handling property that's not theirs". It is an analogy often used in the political or military arena to suggest that if an actor inadvertently creates a problem, the actor is obliged to provide the resources necessary to correct it.[http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2012/07/28/if_you_break_it_do_you_really_have_to_buy_it_.html] ==Origin== The phrase "If you break it, you've bought it" was reportedly first used in 1952 by a Miami Beach gift shop, who posted the message over their fragile merchandise. Individually operated furnishing stores selling fragile goods (art, pottery, and sculptures) often post a "you break it, you buy it" sign. According to legal experts, 'If the sign is big enough, and prominently displayed, it can be argued that you were given what lawyers call "sufficient notice"' and 'In this case, just by entering the store you agree to the terms of the sign, even if you didn't read it'. In addition, it is the customer's responsibility to be careful in a premises with lots of fragile valuable goods; so careless behavior such as an untied shoelace or horsing around can be regarded as negligent. However the rule is rarely enforced, as the establishment cannot detain a customer for non-payment of damages and instead would have to file a civil suit against that customer. In actual practice even a civil suit is unlikely if the patron lacks the means to pay, such as damaged artwork in a museum that could be worth millions. In reality, [[Pottery Barn]]—a chain of upscale home furnishing stores in the United States—does not have a "you break it, you bought it" policy,{{cite web | author=Daniel Grant| year=2005 | title=You Break It, You Buy It? Not According to the Law |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061207233337/http://www.craftsreport.com/april05/break_not_buy.html |archivedate=December 7, 2006 | url=http://www.craftsreport.com/april05/break_not_buy.html| work=[http://www.craftsreport.com/ The Crafts Report Magazine] | accessdate=18 April 2007}} but instead [[Write-off|writes off]] broken merchandise as a loss, as do most large American retailers.{{cite web | author=Helen Huntley| year=2004 | title=Rule that isn't its rule upsets Pottery Barn | url=http://www.sptimes.com/2004/04/20/Business/Rule_that_isn_t_its_r.shtml| work=[http://www.sptimes.com/ St. Petersburg Times] | accessdate=18 April 2007}} Legal doctrine also holds that a retailer incurs the risk that merchandise will be destroyed by placing it where customers can handle it and not doing anything to discourage them. ==Political usage== ''[[New York Times]]'' columnist [[Thomas L. Friedman]] claims to have coined the term, having used the phrase "the pottery store rule" in a February 12, 2003, column. He has said he referred to Pottery Barn specifically in speeches.{{Citation | last = Safire | first = William | title = Language: You break it, you own it, you fix it | newspaper = The New York Times | date = 18 Oct 2004 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2004/10/17/arts/17iht-saf18.html | accessdate = 25 Feb 2014}} According to ''[[Washington Post]]'' journalist [[Bob Woodward]], [[U.S. Secretary of State]] [[Colin Powell]] cited the rule in the summer of 2002 when warning [[President of the United States|President]] [[George W. Bush]] of the consequences of his planned [[Second Iraq War|military action in Iraq]]:
"You are going to be the proud owner of 25 million people," he told the president. "You will own all their hopes, aspirations, and problems. You'll own it all." Privately, Powell and [[Deputy Secretary of State]] [[Richard Armitage (politician)|Richard Armitage]] called this the Pottery Barn rule: You break it, you own it.{{cite book | last = Woodward | first = Bob | authorlink = Bob Woodward | title = [[Plan of Attack]] | year = 2004 | pages=150}}
Powell confirmed the quotation on [[Jonathan Dimbleby]]'s ''Jonathan Dimbleby'' program on April 30, 2006. [[U.S. Democratic Party|Democratic]] presidential candidate [[John Kerry]] cited the rule and attributed it to Powell in debating Bush on policy on the Iraq war during [[2004 Presidential Debates#First presidential debate .E2.80.94 September 30|the first debate of the 2004 Presidential election]]:
KERRY: Secretary of State Colin Powell told this president [Bush] the Pottery Barn rule: If you break it, you fix it. Now, if you break it, you made a mistake. It's the wrong thing to do. But you own it. And then you've got to fix it and do something with it. Now that's what we have to do. There's no inconsistency. Soldiers know over there that this isn't being done right yet. I'm going to get it right for those soldiers, because it's important to Israel, it's important to America, it's important to the world, it's important to the fight on terror. But I have a plan to do it. He [Bush] doesn't.{{cite web|title=Debate Transcript. September 30, 2004 The First Bush-Kerry Presidential Debate|url=http://www.debates.org/index.php?page=september-30-2004-debate-transcript|publisher=Commission on Presidential Debates|accessdate=19 April 2015|date=September 30, 2004}}
Powell denies using the term "pottery barn rule", but stated:
It is said that I used the "Pottery Barn rule." I never did it; [Thomas] Friedman did it… But what I did say…[is that] once you break it, you are going to own it, and we're going to be responsible for 26 million people standing there looking at us. And it's going to suck up a good 40 to 50 percent of the Army for years. And it's going to take all the oxygen out of the political environment…"{{cite web | title=Aspen Ideas Festival | url=https://www.theatlantic.com/doc/200710/aspen-ideas-festival}}
==References== {{Reflist|2}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pottery Barn Rule}} [[Category:Causes and prelude of the Iraq War]] [[Category:International relations terminology]] [[Category:Political terminology of the United States]] [[Category:Williams-Sonoma]]

page.title: Secretary-General's Internal Review Panel on United Nations Action in Sri Lanka

revision.text:
'''Secretary-General's Internal Review Panel (IRP) on United Nations Action in Sri Lanka''' or '''Independent Review Panel on Sri Lanka''' is an internal [[United Nations]] review panel headed by [[Charles Petrie (diplomat)|Charles Petrie]]. The Panel produced a report (Internal Review Panel Report or Petrie report) that describes a "systemic failure" of [[United Nations]] action during the Final Stages of the [[Alleged war crimes during the final stages of the Sri Lankan Civil War|Sri Lankan Civil War]] including the withdrawal of UN staff in September 2008 which removed the 'protection by presence' capacity of the United Nations, shortly before months of intense armed conflict that left tens of thousands of dead. The report suggested that more than 70,000 people may have been killed during approximately the last 6 months of the conflict. The report concludes with a series of recommendations on how the United Nations can strengthen its protection of human rights in similar situations in the future. The report was presented to United Nations Secretary General [[Ban Ki Moon]].
<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=43496#.UTkrszdmOhN|title= Following report on activities in Sri Lanka war, Ban determined to strengthen UN responses to crises |publisher= [[United Nations]]|date= 14 November 2012 |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url= http://www.unmultimedia.org/radio/english/2012/11/un-vows-to-strengthen-response-to-crises-following-sri-lanka-report/|title= UN vows to strengthen response to crises following Sri Lanka report|publisher= [[United Nations]]|date= 16 November 2012 |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/14/world/asia/report-says-un-failed-in-sri-lanka.html?_r=0|title= Report Says U.N. Failed in Sri Lanka|publisher= [[New York Times]]|date= 13 November 2012 |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thesundayleader.lk/2012/11/17/un-review-on-its-conduct-in-sri-lanka-dire-implications/|title= UN Review On Its Conduct In Sri Lanka: Dire Implications|publisher= Sunday Leader|date= |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tamilsagainstgenocide.org/read.aspx?storyid=89|title=Petrie Report |publisher= TAG|date= |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-20308610|title=UN 'failed Sri Lanka civilians', says internal probe|publisher= BBC|date=13 November 2012 |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2012/nov/14/report-damns-un-sri-lanka|title= UN report damns failings during Sri Lankan civil war climax|publisher= Guardian|date=14 November 2012 |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/News/dh/infocus/Sri_Lanka/The_Internal_Review_Panel_report_on_Sri_Lanka.pdf|title= SECRETARY-GENERAL'S INTERNAL REVIEW PANEL. ON UNITED NATIONS ACTION IN SRI LANKA|publisher=[[United Nations]]|date= |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2012/11/14/un-act-failings-sri-lanka|title= UN: Act on Failings in Sri Lanka|publisher=Human Rights Watch|date=November 14, 2012 |accessdate=8 March 2013}}</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=November 2018}} {{good article}} {{Infobox book | name = Sex | image = Cover of Madonna's Sex Book.jpg | caption = The Mylar sheet wrapped cover of ''Sex'', showing Madonna's face | author = [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] | cover_artist = [[Steven Meisel]] | country = United States | genre = {{hlist|[[Sadomasochism|S&M]]|[[fantasy]]|[[erotic photography]]}} | publisher = {{hlist|[[Hachette Book Group USA|Warner Books]]|[[Maverick (company)|Maverick]]|[[Callaway Arts & Entertainment|Callaway]]}} | release_date = October 21, 1992 | media_type = Print (hardback) | isbn = 978-84-406-3117-6 | dewey = 779/.28 | oclc = 26846575 | congress = ML420.M1387 }} '''''Sex''''' is a [[coffee table book]] written by American singer [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], with photographs taken by [[Steven Meisel|Steven Meisel Studio]] and film frames shot by [[Fabien Baron]]. The book was edited by [[Glenn O'Brien]] and was released on October 21, 1992, by [[Hachette Book Group USA|Warner Books]], [[Maverick (company)|Maverick]] and [[Callaway Arts & Entertainment|Callaway]] Books. Approached with an idea for a book on erotic photographs, Madonna expanded on the idea and conceived the book and its content. Shot in early 1992 in New York City and [[Miami]], the locations ranged from hotels and burlesque theaters, to the streets of Miami. The photographs were stolen before publishing, but were quickly recovered.
The book had a range of influences, from punk rock to earlier fashion iconoclasts such as [[Guy Bourdin]], [[Helmut Newton]] and [[Robert Mapplethorpe]]. ''Sex'' has photographs that feature adult content and [[Softcore pornography|softcore pornographic]] as well as simulations of sexual acts, including [[sadomasochism]]. Madonna wrote the book as a character named "Mistress Dita", inspired by 1930s film actress [[Dita Parlo]]. It also includes cameos by actress [[Isabella Rossellini]], rappers [[Big Daddy Kane]] and [[Vanilla Ice]], model [[Naomi Campbell]], gay porn star [[Joey Stefano]], actor [[Udo Kier]], socialite [[Princess Tatiana von Fürstenberg]], and nightclub owner Ingrid Casares.
The packaging for the book is made of aluminium, which was Madonna's idea, and is spiral bound and enclosed in a Mylar sheet. Due to the scandalous nature of the photographs and the media mayhem surrounding it from the initial preview of the book, Madonna did not have to promote ''Sex'', except for a pre-release party and some television specials. Her publishers were extremely apprehensive about the release as well as its commercial potential. ''Sex'' was released alongside her fifth studio album ''[[Erotica (Madonna album)|Erotica]]'', which went on sale a day earlier.
The book was an instant commercial success, managing to sell over 150,000 copies on its first day of release and topping the [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''New York Times'' Best Seller list]]. It was received negatively by both critics and fans of the singer, who felt she had "gone too far." Through the years, however, critical reception towards ''Sex'' has become more positive, with academics deeming it a defining phase in Madonna's career. ''Sex'' is noted for its impact on society and culture as well as on Madonna herself, and is considered a bold, [[post-feminism|post-feminist]] work of art. The book has since become one of the most sought-after out-of-print books ever released and still remains the fastest-selling coffee table book of all time.
== Background and development == According to Giselle Benatar of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'', there are two versions of how Madonna came up with the idea for the book. One was that she conceived the idea of an erotic photography book during the shooting of the film ''[[A League of Their Own]]'' in the summer of 1991.<ref name="Sex and money" /> The second one is that [[Judith Regan]], vice-president and [[editor-in-chief]] of [[Simon & Schuster]], flew to Los Angeles in March 1991 to meet with Madonna and her manager [[Freddy DeMann]], armed with a proposal for a similar collection of photo-erotica.<ref name="Sex and money" /> The singer had initially verified whether Regan had approached any other celebrities with this concept, as Madonna would be interested to be a part of it only if it was a unique idea.<ref>{{harvnb|Taraborrelli|2008|p=230}}</ref> By the end of the meeting Madonna had agreed "in principle" to do a book called ''Madonna's Book of Erotica and Sexual Fantasies''. She told Regan that DeMann would call her and work out the details regarding the book.<ref name="Tarabo 222" /><ref>{{cite news|title=In Time For The Gift-giving Season: Madonna Gets Bookish About|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=October 7, 1992|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1992-10-07/entertainment/9203310949_1_madonna-book-warner-books-miss-america|accessdate=September 18, 2011|first=Michael|last=Kilian|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121007050158/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1992-10-07/entertainment/9203310949_1_madonna-book-warner-books-miss-america|archivedate=October 7, 2012}}</ref> However, Madonna never got back in touch with Regan, who assumed that the singer did not want to proceed with the idea.<ref name="Sex and money" /> Madonna's publicist Liz Rosenberg never confirmed nor denied Regan's claim, but according to Benatar, Madonna started working on ''Sex'' before wrapping up ''A League of Their Own''.<ref name="Sex and money" /> At first [[Warner Bros. Records]] and the executive directors at [[Time Warner]] were reluctant to allow Madonna to publish such a book, but finally gave in to the idea. Madonna, however, was forced to sign a contract that forbade her from showing [[child pornography]], [[bestiality]] and [[religious image]]ry.<ref name="Sex and money" /> Not long after signing this agreement Madonna founded [[Maverick (company)|Maverick]], a multi-media entertainment company. Since by contract she had total artistic control over any of the work released by Maverick, the agreement she signed with Time Warner concerning what not to do in ''Sex'' became obsolete.<ref name="Sun Sentinel" /><ref name="Thomas Mc">{{harvnb|McMahon|2000|pp=702–705}}</ref><ref name="New York Times Warner">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/04/20/arts/madonna-makes-a-60-million-deal.html?pagewanted=2&src=pm|title=Madonna Makes a $60 Million Deal|date=April 20, 1992|accessdate=December 14, 2012|first=Holden|last=Stephen|authorlink=Stephen Holden|work=[[The New York Times]]|pages=1–2|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130524065239/http://www.nytimes.com/1992/04/20/arts/madonna-makes-a-60-million-deal.html?pagewanted=2&src=pm|archivedate=May 24, 2013}}</ref>
[[File:Hotel Chelsea 2010.jpg|upright|thumb|left|Some of the pictures for the project were shot at [[Hotel Chelsea]], New York. ]] The ''Sex'' book had a range of influences—from punk rock to earlier fashion iconoclasts like [[Guy Bourdin]] and his surrealism, and [[Helmut Newton]], in its stylized, sado-masochistic look.<ref name="brien238">{{harvnb|O'Brien|2008|pp=238–239}}</ref> The book was also influenced by [[Robert Mapplethorpe]]'s infamous three-part ''XYZ'' portfolio, particularly the ''X'' portfolio, with Madonna even having considered the latter as a title during the formative stages of ''Sex''.<ref name="Cross 57">{{harvnb|Cross|2007|p=57}}</ref><ref name="Kellner">{{harvnb|Kellner|1995|p=280}}</ref> Photographs from [[Brassaï]]'s 1933 book ''Paris de nuit'' (''Paris by Night'') also inspired several of the book's series of images.<ref name="Cross 57"/><ref name="Kellner"/> Madonna changed her mind about the title being ''X'', when [[Spike Lee]]'s film ''[[Malcolm X (1992 film)|Malcolm X]]'' began to be promoted (the film was released three weeks after the book). She would go on to tell ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' magazine: "We were gonna call it ''X'' [...] but then the whole thing with the Malcolm X movie started. At first I thought, 'Fuck it, it's a really good symbol and I thought of it first'. But I realized it might be confusing or look like I was copying Spike [Lee]. Besides, Sex is almost as powerful: it's universal, it doesn't need translation - and it's only two letters more than X."<ref name="Courant">{{cite web|url=http://articles.courant.com/1992-10-21/features/0000110977_1_gutenberg-bible-madonna-s-new-album-encore-books|title=You Can Tell This Book By Its Cover|date=October 21, 1992|accessdate=December 1, 2012|first=Catlin|last=Roger|work=[[Hartford Courant]]|pages=1–2|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105124754/http://articles.courant.com/1992-10-21/features/0000110977_1_gutenberg-bible-madonna-s-new-album-encore-books|archivedate=November 5, 2012}}</ref> Warner Bros. commented that ''Sex'' was very difficult to produce, requiring contributions from many different printing and publishing companies.<ref name="tres" /> They also stated that in order to generate any profit, the book would have to sell at least 350,000 copies.<ref name="DigitalSpy" /><ref name="The Girl EW" /> Madonna hired top-notch talent for the development of the book;<ref name="Cross 57"/> she counted on the help of friends from the music, film and fashion industry.<ref name="tres" /> The singer hired [[Fabien Baron]] as the art director,<ref name="Fabien Baron the">{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/1992/11/29/fabien-baron-s-grand-designs.html|title=Fabien Baron's Grand Designs|date=November 29, 1992|accessdate=December 13, 2012|first=Jones|last=Malcolm|work=The Daily Beast|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130411230917/http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/1992/11/29/fabien-baron-s-grand-designs.html|archivedate=April 11, 2013}}</ref> fashion photographer [[Steven Meisel]], editor [[Glenn O'Brien]], make-up artist Francois Nars and hairstylist Paul Cavaco.<ref name="Sex and money" /><ref name="Thomas Mc" /><ref name="New York Times dos" /> Madonna originally wanted the book to be of an oval shape in order to simulate a [[condom]] but the printing and manufacturing of such a book would have been too expensive. Meisel would later comment: "Madonna and I can keep up with each other" and that "I'm doing things to make people think too. It's not really to antagonize or to push people's buttons. It's really to present another way of seeing things."<ref name="Sex and money" />
The pictures were taken almost entirely in [[Super 8 film|Super 8]] format, and most of the photo shoots took place in New York City and [[Miami]]. Locations in New York City included the [[Hotel Chelsea]] and Times Square's all-male burlesque [[Gaiety Theatre, New York (male burlesque)|Gaiety Theatre]] (dancers from theatre participated in one of the book's photo sessions), whereas in Miami the majority of the sessions were shot at a house Madonna had purchased just before starting the project, and in several beaches and streets.<ref name="Sex and money" /><ref name="Sun Sentinel" /><ref name="Chelsea">{{cite web|url=http://www.chelseahotelblog.com/living_with_legends_the_h/rock_roll/|title=You Can Tell This Book By Its Cover|accessdate=December 14, 2012|work=[[Hotel Chelsea]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121211043928/http://www.chelseahotelblog.com/living_with_legends_the_h/rock_roll/|archivedate=December 11, 2012}}</ref> One morning during the four-day Florida shoot Madonna was prancing around her 14-bedroom house in Miami completely naked, when someone jokingly suggested she go out on the street, then, according to Baron "the next thing we're in the street" where allegedly "cars screeched to a halt, motorists whistled, and one entranced cyclist fell off his bike."<ref name="Sex and money" /> This was just one of the many crazy episodes that took place during the shooting of the book. According to Baron, during the photo shoots "[Madonna]'d do something crazy and then we'd come up with something even crazier". One of the most shocking photographs made for the book, which featured two women in [[post-punk]] attire flanking Madonna with one of them holding a knife to Madonna's crotch, was dismissed as it was considered too violent. At some point, while the book was being produced, some of the photographs were stolen, but were quickly recovered by the [[FBI]].<ref name="Sex and money" /> According to ''[[New York (magazine)|New York]]'' magazine, there were approximately 80,000 photographs taken for the book,<ref name="Nyissue" /> but only a handful made the final cut.<ref name="Sex and money" /> The printing of the book was extended for 15 days<ref name="The Girl EW" /> making the total production process last about eight months.<ref name="Tarabo 224" />
== Design and content == [[File:Madonna HRCP (cropped).jpg|thumb|The picture shows the leather string worn by Madonna in the ''Sex'' book, as well as in the "[[Erotica (song)|Erotica]]" music video. Below the string, an image from the book can also be seen.]]
Wrapped and sealed in a [[polyethylene terephthalate]] (PET) Mylar bag,<ref name="The Daily Beast">{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/1992/11/01/the-selling-of-sex.html|title=The Selling of Sex|date=November 1, 1992|accessdate=December 6, 2012|work=[[The Daily Beast]]|pages=1–3|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20130411222601/http://www.thedailybeast.com/newsweek/1992/11/01/the-selling-of-sex.html|archivedate=April 11, 2013}}</ref><ref name="Cross 58">{{harvnb|Cross|2007|p=58}}</ref><ref name="Publishers">{{cite journal|title=Publishers on File: Madonna|date=September 20, 1992|work=Facts on File, Inc|publisher=Publishers on File|volume=23|issue= 2|pages=3, 27}}</ref> ''Sex'' contains 128 pages and is [[Coil binding|spiral bound]] with an [[aluminium]] cover that has the word "Sex" stamped in the middle<ref name="New York Times dos" /><ref name="The Morning Call" /> and a warning label.<ref name="Courant dos">{{cite web|url=http://articles.courant.com/1992-10-18/entertainment/0000111080_1_warner-books-callaway-editions-nation-s-two-largest-bookstore|title=Area Booksellers Wonder If Customers Will Pay $50 For 'Sex' With|date=October 18, 1992|accessdate=December 12, 2012|first=McClurg|last=Jocelyn|work=[[Hartford Courant]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130615140223/http://articles.courant.com/1992-10-18/entertainment/0000111080_1_warner-books-callaway-editions-nation-s-two-largest-bookstore|archivedate=June 15, 2013}}</ref> The front page also shows Madonna against a sky blue backdrop.<ref name="The Morning Call">{{cite news|url=http://articles.mcall.com/1992-11-05/news/2888489_1_madonna-book-joan-lunden-carbon-county|title='Sex' Book: It Is Merely An Investment|date=October 5, 1992|accessdate=December 1, 2012|first=Braden|last=Tyra|work=[[The Morning Call]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120606142453/http://articles.mcall.com/1992-11-05/news/2888489_1_madonna-book-joan-lunden-carbon-county|archivedate=June 6, 2012}}</ref> Three different types of paper were used for the printing of ''Sex'' and the design was overseen by Madonna and Baron & Baron Inc. (consisting of Fabien Baron and the photographer Siung Fat Tjia) who had previously collaborated with the singer designing the cover art of her fifth studio album, ''[[Erotica (Madonna album)|Erotica]]''.<ref name="The Girl EW" /><ref name="Fabien Biography">{{cite web|url=http://www.bernhardtdesignpress.com/downloads/BaronBio03_25_03.pdf|title=Fabien Baron Biography|accessdate=December 14, 2012|first=Baron|last=Fabien|publisher=BernhardtDesignPress.com|pages=1–2|format=PDF|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324130040/http://www.bernhardtdesignpress.com/downloads/BaronBio03_25_03.pdf|archivedate=March 24, 2012}}</ref> As this was the first project for Maverick, the packaging was crucial; however Madonna did not have faith in Warner Book's "mass-market" publication process. Hence Baron suggested to transfer the packaging job to [[Nicholas Callaway]]'s bespoke Callaway Editions.<ref name="brien240" /> Charles Melcher, co-publisher with Callaway for the book, said that they usually did "exquisite art books, $100 high end, beautiful things". But it was a challenge for them to process Madonna's ideas into reality. The artist wanted the packaging to be sealed, so that the reader had to tear it up and read.<ref name="brien240" /> They considered various kinds of clasps before zeroing on the idea of the sealed bag as a reference to a condom package. The metal cover was Madonna's idea, who took the inspiration from the 1979 album, ''[[Metal Box]]'' by the band [[Public Image Ltd]].<ref name="brien241" /> Melcher recollects, "We were talking about materials for the cover, and we went into her kitchen. [Madonna] pointed at the metal plate at the back of her stove and said, 'I want something like this'. I was very impressed with the way she interacted with her world to source things."<ref name="brien241">{{harvnb|O'Brien|2008|p=241}}</ref> The company bought about {{convert|1,500,000|lb|kg}} of aluminium, a pound for each book. The designers had to do the front and the back covers, while rolling, stamping and ionizing the metal.<ref name="brien241" />
The book opens up with the introduction: "Everything you are about to see and read is a fantasy, a dream, pretend".<ref name="EW 2002">{{cite web|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,365681,00.html|title=The Naked Launch|date=October 25, 2002|accessdate=November 30, 2012|first=Kirschling|last=Gregory|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130115134604/http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,365681,00.html|archivedate=January 15, 2013}}</ref> Throughout ''Sex'', Madonna offers poems, stories, and essays.<ref name="Sun Sentinel">{{cite web|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1992-10-18/features/9202240139_1_madonna-big-book-orders|title=Madonna She's Got Sex For Our Eyes And Erotica For Our Ears.|date=November 5, 1992|accessdate=December 12, 2012|first=Deborah|last=Wilker|work=[[Sun-Sentinel]]|pages=1–2|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140222042606/http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1992-10-18/features/9202240139_1_madonna-big-book-orders|archivedate=February 22, 2014}}</ref> She also uses the [[pseudonym]] "Mistress Dita" as a homage to German actress [[Dita Parlo]]; her friends in these stories are Bunny, Dex, Stella, Chiclet and Stranger.<ref name="Tarabo 222">{{harvnb|Taraborrelli|2008|p=231}}</ref><ref name="McNair" /> According to biographer J. Randy Taraborrelli, a big part of the book is read as a letter to a [[pornographic magazine]].<ref name="Tarabo 222" /> As a thank you for recovering the stolen pictures during the making of the book, in the credits of the book Madonna mentioned the FBI for " ... rescuing photographs that would have made [[J. Edgar Hoover]] roll over."<ref name="New York Times dos" /><ref name="TI">{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/madonna-at-50-899782.html|title=Madonna at 50|date=August 17, 2008|accessdate=December 18, 2012|first=Katy|last=Guest|work=[[The Independent]]|location=London|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121211114526/http://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/music/features/madonna-at-50-899782.html|archivedate=December 11, 2012}}</ref> Madonna also wanted to explore the notion of power in ''Sex''. Melcher said that the artist wanted to talk about "gentle and hard, soft and violent [in ''Sex'']. She was playing out all those elements in her book. That was reflected in the materials: uncoated, soft paper on the inside and hard metal coating on the outside."<ref name="brien240">{{harvnb|O'Brien|2008|p=240}}</ref>
Just like the text—which was mostly written on top of photographs—the photographs on the book are highly sexual and depict [[nudity]], simulations of sexual acts, [[Bondage (BDSM)|bondage]], [[homosexuality]] and [[Anal–oral sex|analingus]], with accessories such as knives, whips, masks and chains;<ref name="Sun Sentinel" /><ref name="Nyissue">{{cite journal|date=October 12, 1992|title=Madonna's Magician|work=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|pages=28–36|location=New York|volume=25|issn=0028-7369|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oOQCAAAAMBAJ&pg=RA1-PA32&dq=Madonna+-+Sex&hl=es&sa=X&ei=V2-5UIe7J8aZyQH9nYDoCg&ved=0CEQQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=Madonna%20-%20Sex&f=false}}</ref><ref name="Leo" /><ref name="Scott 96" /> however, full [[sexual intercourse|intercourse]] is never shown.<ref name="New York Times dos" /> Aside from unknown models, featured in the book are actress [[Isabella Rossellini]], rappers [[Big Daddy Kane]] and Madonna's then boyfriend [[Vanilla Ice]],<ref name="Tarabo 224">{{harvnb|Taraborrelli|2008|p=233}}</ref> model [[Naomi Campbell]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Campbell defends nude Madonna book pictures|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=February 12, 2002|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2002/feb/12/pressandpublishing.privacy3|accessdate=September 18, == Release and promotion == The initial preview of the book was met with a huge amount of controversy, as it showed a nude Madonna wearing a rabbit's tail, shaving the [[pubic hair]] of a naked man, and cavorting outdoors with a dog, suggesting [[zoophilia|bestiality]].<ref name="Courant" /><ref name="Nyissue" /> [[The Holy See|The Vatican]] urged its people to boycott the release, saying that it was "morally intolerable".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=LA&p_theme=la&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EF617A7CABA631F&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=How Far Can She Go?|date=October 11, 1992|accessdate=June 8, 2013|work=Daily News of Los Angeles}}</ref> Indian customs officials said that the book offended the country's public morality. The [[Press Trust of India]] (PTI), India's domestic news agency, quoted a top customs official as saying the book would be seized under a section of the Customs Act prohibiting entry of indecent literature.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=PI&s_site=philly&p_multi=PI&p_theme=realcities&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB2A40D2B478A8E&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=India Will Slam Madonna's Book Shut|date=November 2, 1992|accessdate=June 8, 2013|work=Philadelphia Inquirer|last=Morani|first=Jignesh}}</ref> Citizens of [[Alexandria, Louisiana]] filed a complaint with the city's police department on behalf of a group called the Rapides Parish Chapter of American Family Association, claiming that it violated Louisiana's anti-obscenity laws.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=AD&p_theme=ad&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB4770DCEE7214B&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=Citizen says Madonna's "Sex" violates anti-obscenity laws|date=October 2, 1992|accessdate=June 8, 2013|work=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]}}</ref> South US Baptists did not want their Bibles coming off the same printing presses as Madonna's ''Sex'' and threatened to stop doing business with a Chicago printer. The Nashville-based Baptist Sunday School Board, a division of the Southern Baptist Convention, reviewed their $2.1 million (${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|2100000|1992}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) printing contract with R.R. Donnelley & Sons. Board President James Draper said he was infuriated that Donnelley also printed "such an obscene book".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=RO&p_theme=ro&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EAEA2F3934F4B49&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title='Sex' Printer May Lose Church Trade|date=October 30, 1992|accessdate=June 8, 2013|work=[[The Roanoke Times]]}}</ref> ''[[Entertainment Tonight]]'' reported that Madonna herself had initiated the mayhem with the explicit content in the music video for "Erotica", walking bare breasted at designer Jean Paul Gaultier's fashion show and posing nude in ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'' magazine.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Hart|first=Mary|title=Will She Do It?|authorlink=Mary Hart|work=[[Entertainment Tonight]]|date=October 14, 1992}}</ref> A writer for ''[[The Sacramento Bee]]'' said that since the press wanted "controversy", Madonna was willing to provide them "fodder" with her "antiques".<ref>{{cite news|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=SB&p_theme=sb&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EB0DA009B6B202A&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|title=The Madonna Media Machine|date=October 20, 1992|accessdate=June 8, 2013|work=[[The Sacramento Bee]]}}</ref>
{{double image|left|Vanilla Ice.jpg|145|NaomiCampbell.jpg|150|Rapper [[Vanilla Ice]] (''left'') and model [[Naomi Campbell]] (''right'') are among the celebrities that appeared in the book. Both appeared in explicit images alongside Madonna.|||}} Madonna then said she was "doing this to liberate America — free us all of our hang-ups".<ref name="Sun Sentinel" /> She told ''Spin'' magazine "We live in a very repressed society, and I deal with erotic themes. The point I try to make is: Why should we feel ashamed of our sexuality?".<ref name="Bob" /> Later she revealed that "[This book] does not condone unsafe sexual practices".<ref name="Tarabo 222" /> Nicholas Callaway from [[Callaway Arts & Entertainment]] said that the book was "inevitably going to be controversial. The book explores every aspect of sexual fantasy. It's hard to calculate the effect, [but], ''Sex'' should be considered 'art'".<ref name="Chicago Tr">{{cite web|url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1992-10-07/entertainment/9203310949_1_madonna-book-warner-books-miss-america|title=In Time For The Gift-giving Season: Madonna Gets Bookish About|date=October 7, 1992|accessdate=December 13, 2012|first=Kilian|last=Michael|work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121007050158/http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1992-10-07/entertainment/9203310949_1_madonna-book-warner-books-miss-america|archivedate=October 7, 2012}}</ref> Originally it was rumored that [[Time Warner]] was nervous about the release of the book; however, in an interview with ''[[Vanity Fair (magazine)|Vanity Fair]]'', William Sarnoff, president of Warner Books, said he felt that Madonna "should pursue all avenues of creativity as she defines it". The Warner company had also previously assured that they would make sure ''Sex'' reached its main [[target audience]] and also reminded that the book was safely wrapped in a Mylar bag to prevent in-store peeping and contained a warning label.<ref name="Sun Sentinel" /> [[Michael Kilian]] of the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' published an article on October 7, 1992, regarding the then upcoming release of ''Sex'': "Prepare thyself, [...], The mega-event of the millennium is to occur in precisely two weeks. It's an event far more mega than the November election, the collapse of communism or even the crowning of [[Leanza Cornett]] as the new [[Miss America]]." Kilian also described it as the "personal sexual fantasy picture book in all Christendom, then it goes far beyond all previous 'truly twisted' personal sexual fantasy picture books—perhaps beyond all imagining what such a book could be".<ref name="Chicago Tr" />
On October 15, Madonna threw a pre-release party at New York City's Industria Superstudio, and signed all the invitations under her ''Sex'' [[alter ego]] "Dita".<ref name="Vogue It">{{cite web |url=http://www.vogue.it/en/people-are-talking-about/from-new-york/2011/03/industria-superstudio-anniversary|title=Industria Anniversary|date=March 29, 2011|accessdate=December 12, 2012|first=D'Annunzio|last=Grazia|work=[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]}}</ref><ref name="Signed">{{cite web|url=http://www.julienslive.com/view-auctions/catalog/id/26/lot/7299/|title=Madonna Signed Invitation|accessdate=December 10, 2012|first=Darren|last=Julien|publisher=[[Julien's Auctions]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130701170111/http://www.julienslive.com/view-auctions/catalog/id/26/lot/7299/|archivedate=July 1, 2013}}</ref> During the party, Madonna showed up dressed as [[Little Bo Peep]] and even carried with her a stuffed toy lamb.<ref name="TI" /> Madonna's publicist Liz Rosenberg showed concern at first due to "what the parents of America's impressionable teens will soon be thinking" but later said that it "all depends on your idea of lovemaking, which in Madonna's case, should give new meaning to the word erotic".<ref name="Sun Sentinel" /> Both [[Waldenbooks]] and [[Barnes & Noble]] prepared corporate statements that the managers could share with customers who are offended by ''Sex''. (Both statements defended the right of bookstores to provide "diversity and choice" to customers and say censorship is not the role of bookstores.)<ref name="Courant dos" /> Many book stores, too, stated that the book would not be sold to anyone under 18 and that it would be for display only behind the cash register.<ref name="Sun Sentinel" /><ref name="Courant dos" /> Bookstore owner David Epstein stated that "The feeling of most people who have ordered the book is that Madonna is something special, that this is cutting-edge art, [...], they're not the kind of people who are buying it because it's smut and dirty pictures. People are interested in it as art."<ref name="Courant dos" />
''Sex'' was finally released on October 21, 1992 – one day after Madonna's fifth studio album ''[[Erotica (Madonna album)|Erotica]]'' – by editorials Callaway and [[Warner Books]];<ref name="Sun Sentinel" /><ref name="New York Times dos" /><ref name="Chicago Tr" /><ref name="New York Times one" /><ref name="New York Times two" /> it was the first work released by Madonna's company Maverick.<ref name="Sex and money" /><ref name="Sun Sentinel" /> A [[comic book]] titled ''Dita in The Chelsea Girl'' was included in the book. Also included was a promotional single titled "Erotic" with the CD packaging representing a condom wrapper.<ref name="Cross 57"/><ref name="Kellner"/> The track "Erotic" featured a stripped-down arrangement of the song "[[Erotica (song)|Erotica]]" that offered an alternate vocal take not used in the album version. With an initial print run of one million copies of the first edition in five continents and in five languages,<ref name="New York Times two" /> the price of the book was $50 (${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|50|1992}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) at retail, making sex an "expensive visual book".<ref name="Chicago Tr" /><ref name="New York Times one">{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/10/19/business/the-media-business-edging-into-madonna-s-limelight.html?scp=3&sq=madonna%20sex&st=cse|title=The Media Business; Edging Into Madonna's Limelight|date=October 20, 1992|accessdate=December 13, 2012|first=Shapiro|last=Eben|work=[[The New York Times]]|page=1|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130524101611/http://www.nytimes.com/1992/10/19/business/the-media-business-edging-into-madonna-s-limelight.html?scp=3&sq=madonna%20sex&st=cse|archivedate=May 24, 2013}}</ref> Nevertheless, the book managed to break records regarding the number of copies pre-ordered before the release. Nicholas Callaway pointed out that the book was an unprecedented hit, because the print run of an average art book ranges between 5 and 10,000 units.<ref name="The Girl EW" /> He described it as "the largest initial release of any illustrated book in publishing history".<ref name="DigitalSpy" /><ref name="The Girl EW">{{cite news|url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,312251,00.html|title=The Girl Can't Help It|date=September 25, 1992|accessdate=December 14, 2012|first=Sharon|last=Isaak|first2=Tina|last2=Jordan|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HIKwbPLs?url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,312251,00.html|archivedate=June 11, 2013}}</ref>
Due to the high scandal and controversy surrounding the book, there was not really any need for Madonna to promote it;<ref name="Leo">{{harvnb|Tassoni|1993|p=22}}</ref> however, one of the few promotions for the book Madonna did, was appearing on the cover of the October edition of ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'', where she appeared dressed in "Hippie trip" fashion. These photographs were taken by Meisel.<ref name="Vogue">{{cite news|url=http://www.vogue.com/voguepedia/Madonna|title=Madonna Reinvented for the very last time|date=February 14, 2011|accessdate=December 21, 2012|work=[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130129103222/http://www.vogue.com/voguepedia/Madonna|archivedate=January 29, 2013}}</ref> After the book was released, on October 22, 1992, [[MTV]] aired a special called ''The Day in Madonna'', hosted by [[Kurt Loder]] (the title of this special was a pun of the title of the channel's daily show ''The Day in Rock''), which profiled the release of Madonna's ''Sex'' and her album ''Erotica'', even taking the book to the streets to allow people, including a sex therapist and group of real-life New York City [[Dominatrix|dominatrices]], to view it. MTV also interviewed many people who had viewed the book on the day of its release at the HMV music store in New York City. In celebration of the release of the book, the store held a Madonna look-alike contest and set up a booth where people could view the book for one dollar a minute, with all of the proceeds going to Lifebeat, the music industry organization founded to help fund AIDS research.<ref name="tres">{{harvnb|Anderson|Reckhenrich|Kupp|2011|p=109}}</ref>
== Critical and commercial reception == {{Quote box |quote="I don't think sex is bad. I don't think nudity is bad. I don't think that being in touch with your sexuality and being able to talk about it is bad. I think the problem is that everybody's so uptight about it and have turned it into something bad when it isn't. If people could talk about it freely, we would have more people practicing safe sex, we wouldn't have people sexually abusing each other.|source = – Madonna discussing the backlash surrounding the book.<ref name="Cross 57" /> |width = 25% |align = left }} The book received negative reaction from critics,<ref name="New York Times two" /><ref>{{cite news|title=You can tell this book by its cover Sex' is out a day after Madonna's new album|work=[[Hartford Courant]]|date=October 21, 1992|url=http://articles.courant.com/1992-10-21/features/0000110977_1_gutenberg-bible-madonna-s-new-album-encore-books|accessdate=September 18, 2011|last=Catlin|first=Roger|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121105124754/http://articles.courant.com/1992-10-21/features/0000110977_1_gutenberg-bible-madonna-s-new-album-encore-books|archivedate=November 5, 2012}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title= Sex Book: It Is Merely An Investment|work= [[The Morning Call]]|date= November 5, 1992|url= http://articles.mcall.com/1992-11-05/news/2888489_1_madonna-book-joan-lunden-carbon-county|accessdate= September 18, 2011|deadurl= no|archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20120606142453/http://articles.mcall.com/1992-11-05/news/2888489_1_madonna-book-joan-lunden-carbon-county|archivedate= June 6, 2012|df= mdy-all}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Books of The Times; Madonna Writes; Academics Explore Her Erotic Semiotics|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=October 21, 1992|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1992/10/21/books/books-of-the-times-madonna-writes-academics-explore-her-erotic-semiotics.html|accessdate=September 19, 2011|first=Michiko|last=Kakutani|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120203115602/http://www.nytimes.com/1992/10/21/books/books-of-the-times-madonna-writes-academics-explore-her-erotic-semiotics.html|archivedate=February 3, 2012}}</ref> conservative and [[feminism|feminist]] [[Opposition to pornography|anti-porn]] groups,<ref name="Sex and money" /><ref name="Macdonald">{{harvnb|McDonald|2001|p=35}}</ref> due to its sexually explicit photographs which many characterized as [[hardcore pornography]].<ref name="Chapman">{{harvnb|Chapman|2010|p=333}}</ref> Taraborrelli opined that much of the book appears surprising and not shocking.<ref name="tara232">{{harvnb|Taraborrelli|2008|p=232}}</ref> He derided the whole concept as childish and impetuous rather than an adult book. According to him, though Madonna insisted that she was trying to demystify sexuality altogether, the author believed she just wanted to publish pornographic text and pictures and get away with it. "She was being a brat, not a revolutionary", the author concluded.<ref name="tara232" /> Author [[Lucy O'Brien]] declared that the book was a bold, harrowing exercise in frustration, and despite Madonna's attempt at invincibility, the book appeared as "a curious act of self-destruction".<ref>{{harvnb|O'Brien|2008|pp=211–212}}</ref> "The overwhelming effect of the book is numbing," stated Anthony DeCurtis of ''[[Rolling Stone]]''. "The images are derivative, and Madonna herself seems far too eager to shock; that, not even prurient arousal, seems the ideal response the book tirelessly seeks. Roger Catlin from the ''[[Hartford Courant]]'' said that the passages from the book were "too dirty to quote here, even the funny ones".<ref name="Courant" /> ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' said that "the book is neither groundbreaking (save that it features a major star) nor particularly sexy [...] ''Sex'' is convincing only when it's playful, as when she appears nude in a Miami pizzeria, chewing a slice while a baffled customer looks on. Elsewhere, she's simply undressed with no place to go".<ref name="The Daily Beast" /> Richard Harrington from ''[[The Washington Post]]'' gave the book a mixed review by saying: "Is ''Sex'' shocking? not really. Weekly]]|pages=1–3|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6HIKwbPLs?url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,312251,00.html|archivedate=June 11, 2013}}</ref> and eventually topped [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''The New York Times'' Best Seller list]].<ref name="Tarabo 224" /> Giselle Benatar wrote in her article "Sex & Money": "This isn't the publishing event of the year, it's the publishing event of the century."<ref name="Sex and money" /> A day earlier, Tyra Braden from ''[[The Morning Call]]'' wrote that she and some friends concluded that the book "might become a collector's item a few years down the road".<ref name="The Morning Call" /> ''Sex'' went on to sell 1.5 million copies worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.accesshollywood.com/articles/madonna-the-first-50-years-64926/|title=Madonna: The First 50 Years|date=August 16, 2008|accessdate=February 2, 2017|work=[[Access Hollywood]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170211082009/https://www.accesshollywood.com/articles/madonna-the-first-50-years-64926/|archivedate=February 11, 2017}}</ref>
== Social impact and aftermath == [[File:EroticaGirlieShowUnderGround sh.jpg|thumb|upright|Madonna's performances in [[The Girlie Show World Tour]] faced negative reactions from conservative groups, who deemed the singer immoral.]] Dubbed at the time as the "Queen of obscene",<ref name="Kirk Davidson">{{Harvnb|Davidson|2003|p=100}}</ref> Madonna and the ''Sex'' era is considered by many as her most controversial and transgressive period.<ref name="Cambio">{{cite web|url=http://www.cambio.com.co/entretenimientocambio/791/ARTICULO-WEB-NOTA_INTERIOR_CAMBIO-4470108.html|title=Madonna, vigente a los 50|date=November 2, 2008|accessdate=February 21, 2013|language=Spanish|trans-title=Madonna, still got it at 50|publisher=Cambio.com. [[AOL]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515143201/http://www.cambio.com.co/entretenimientocambio/791/ARTICULO-WEB-NOTA_INTERIOR_CAMBIO-4470108.html|archivedate=May 15, 2013}}</ref><ref name="EMOL bio" /> The book, widely panned by the press, is regarded as one of the factors that shaped the social reaction and critique towards Madonna during the early 1990s.<ref name="Scott 96" /> Her fifth studio album ''[[Erotica (Madonna album)|Erotica]]'' was affected by the negative press surrounding the book.<ref name="BBC Ne">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7447895.stm|title=Pop superstars turn 50|date=August 15, 2008|accessdate=December 7, 2012|first=Wright|last=Alan|publisher=[[BBC News]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120802072509/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/7447895.stm|archivedate=August 2, 2012}}</ref> In March 1993, ''Spin'' magazine wrote an article praising the book,<ref name="Spin">{{cite journal|date=March 21, 1993|title=Point Black Letter|work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|pages=17|volume=8|issue=12|issn=0886-3032|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=6ADSCfip83cC&pg=PA18}}</ref> but months later in Mexico, [[social communication|social communicologist]] Nino Canún dedicated an episode of his morning [[talk show]] ''¿Y usted qué opina?'' (English: ''So what's your opinion?''), to Madonna. Some members of the audience, among them a [[Priesthood (Catholic Church)|priest]], presented their arguments as to why "this morally clueless singer shouldn't be allowed to perform in the country", making reference to [[The Girlie Show World Tour]], which was set to visit Mexico. Later, during the concert, Madonna wore a ''[[charro]]'' [[sombrero]] and simulated an [[orgy]] with her dancers onstage, as a response to these comments.<ref name="Vanguardia">{{cite news|url=http://www.vanguardia.com.mx/madonnaenmexicoconfiesaquehapecado-1426520.html|title=Madonna en México: Confiesa que ha pecado|last=Vázquez Galindo|first=Humberto|date=November 26, 2012|accessdate=February 21, 2013|language=Spanish|work=[[Vanguardia (newspaper)|Vanguardia]]|location=Santa Clara|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131207101039/http://www.vanguardia.com.mx/madonnaenmexicoconfiesaquehapecado-1426520.html|archivedate=December 7, 2013}}</ref> Continuing her provocative imagery, Madonna starred in the erotic thriller ''[[Body of Evidence (1993 film)|Body of Evidence]]'', which featured the singer fully nude and in scenes engaged in simulated sexual acts.<ref>{{harvnb|Metz|Benson|1999|pp=17–20}}</ref> In March 1994, [[Madonna on Late Show with David Letterman in 1994|Madonna appeared as a guest]] on ''[[Late Show with David Letterman]]'', using profanity that was required to be censored on television and handing Letterman a pair of her underwear and asking him to smell it.<ref>{{harvnb|Tetzlaff|1993|p=143}}</ref> The releases of her sexually explicit film, album and book, and the aggressive appearance on Letterman all made critics regard Madonna as a sexual renegade. She faced strong negative publicity from critics and fans, who commented that "she had gone too far" and that her career was over.<ref>{{harvnb|Taraborrelli|2008|pp=245}}</ref> Later, on the song "[[Human Nature (Madonna song)|Human Nature]]", from her sixth studio album ''[[Bedtime Stories (Madonna album)|Bedtime Stories]]'' (1994), Madonna addressed the public backlash the book was still receiving, particularly with the lines "Did I say something wrong? Oops, I didn't know I couldn't talk about sex. I must have been crazy," as well as the line "What was I thinking?".<ref name="Scott 96" />
{{quote|The perfect iconic goddess of ''[[True Blue (Madonna album)|True Blue]]'' had all gone. In the same way that sixties beauties like [[Nico]], [[Marianne Faithfull]] and [[Brigitte Bardot]] set about destroying their beauty after they were famous, the very thing they felt limited them, Madonna annihilated hers. Within a few short years she moved from teasing flirtation to desperate sexual display. It is ironic that after the triumph of ''[[Like a Prayer (album)|Like a Prayer]]'', she hits this bathos. Being a blond again set her off in the wrong direction. It was as if with the ''Sex'' book she showed the underside of the Hollywood dream.|Lucy O'Brien, ''Madonna: Like an Icon'', page. 254<ref>{{harvnb|O'Brien|2008|p=254}}</ref>}}
{{Quote box |quote=In ''Sex'' [Madonna] of course, was saying ''exactly'' what she wanted, warts and all... Indeed, this idea that she was penning her own sexual narrative was perhaps the most shocking part of the whole enterprise. And while it was easy to critique ''Sex'', it should be applauded for this balls-to-the-wall honesty.|source =—Priya Elan discussing the book.<ref name=Guardian>{{cite web|last1=Elan|first1=Priya|title=Looking back at Madonna and Sex|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/shortcuts/2012/apr/25/looking-back-at-madonna-sex|work=[[The Guardian]]|accessdate=January 7, 2016|date=April 25, 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303051254/http://www.theguardian.com/music/shortcuts/2012/apr/25/looking-back-at-madonna-sex|archivedate=March 3, 2016|df=mdy-all}}</ref> |width = 25% |align = left }} Madonna herself would later say: "I wouldn't say I regret it. I've made mistakes and learned from them. Most people want to hear me say that I regret publishing my ''Sex'' book. I don't. The problem was releasing my ''Erotica'' album at the same time. I love that album and it got overlooked."<ref name="Allen Metz y Carol Benson">{{harvnb|Metz|Benson|1999|p=78}}</ref><ref name="Bego">{{harvnb|Bego|2000|p=288}}</ref> However, author Andy Koopmans in his book ''Madonna'' (2002) would comment that the singer regretted both publishing ''Sex'' and recording ''Erotica'' and that the book "had affected everything she did later".<ref name="Andy Koopmas">{{harvnb|Koopmans|2002|p=86}}</ref> It was not until 2003 that Madonna would once again declare that she regretted nothing; "I'm not apologizing in any shape or form [...] I was interested in pushing buttons and being rebellious and being mischievous and trying to bend the rules. There was a lot of irony in the ''Sex'' book and I am poking fun at a lot of things and I am being kind of silly and adolescent and I am being very f you, if a man can do it, I can do it."<ref name="The Sydney Morning Herald">{{cite news|url=http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/09/15/1063478100493.html?from=storyrhs|title=Madonna stays mum on sex|date=September 15, 2003|accessdate=December 8, 2012|last=Stonewall|first=Jessica|work=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130101132453/http://www.smh.com.au/articles/2003/09/15/1063478100493.html?from=storyrhs|archivedate=January 1, 2013}}</ref> A year earlier on 2002, Naomi Campbell confessed to "have a lot of respect for Madonna being bold enough to come out and do a book on sex. I've never reneged on that".<ref name="The Guardian Campbell">{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2002/feb/12/pressandpublishing.privacy3|title=Campbell defends nude Madonna book pictures|date=February 12, 2002|accessdate=December 13, 2012|first=Milmo|last=Dan|work=[[The Guardian]]|location=London|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130826001042/http://www.theguardian.com/media/2002/feb/12/pressandpublishing.privacy3|archivedate=August 26, 2013}}</ref> However, in 2009, rapper Vanilla Ice, who was Madonna's boyfriend at the time of the book's creation, confessed to not being happy with the book once he saw it. "My friends were like, 'Dude, that's cool man', but I was like, 'I'm dating her, it's not cool to see your girlfriend with all these other people' [...] It kinda ruined the whole thing. I wonder what her kids think of that book? Here she is writing kids' books now but they're going to see it and go, 'Mommy, what were you thinking?'"<ref name="Vanilla Ice Herald">{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/ice-cold-on-exs-sex-book/story-e6frf7jo-1225698249712|title=Ice cold on Madonna's sex book|date=April 2, 2009|accessdate=December 13, 2012|first=Adams|last=Cameron|work=[[Herald Sun (Australia)|Herald Sun]]}}</ref> Another of the book's models, actress Isabella Rossellini, told ''[[Out (magazine)|Out]]'' magazine that she regretted her participation on the book; "I don't think the book worked, even though the photos were extraordinary, and some of them quite memorable. I think there was a little bit of a moralistic sort of 'I'll teach you how to be free!' – and that bothered the hell out of me."<ref name="San Francisco Chronicle">{{cite news|url=http://blog.sfgate.com/dailydish/2010/12/09/isabella-rossellini-regrets-madonnas-sex-book/|title=Isabella Rossellini regrets Madonna's sex book|date=December 2, 2009|accessdate=December 13, 2012|last=Ivans|first=Laurie|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130523200206/http://blog.sfgate.com/dailydish/2010/12/09/isabella-rossellini-regrets-madonnas-sex-book/|archivedate=May 23, 2013}}</ref>
Later reviews towards ''Sex'' have become more positive. The authors of ''The Porning of America: The Rise of Porn Culture, What It Means, and Where We Go from Here'' (2008) have commented that "the book is particularly interesting in the way that, like many of Madonna's works, it portrays sex in terms of domination and power",<ref name="Scott 96" /> whereas Jane Raphaely, editor-in-chief of ''[[Cosmopolitan (magazine)|Cosmopolitan]]'' praised Madonna's "liberated behavior on ''Sex'' [...] the fact that she takes all forms of pornography and systematically demystifies it by putting it under her control", in an article in 1996.<ref name="Bell Klein">{{harvnb|Bell|Klein|1996|pp=431–432}}</ref> Brian McNair, author of ''Striptease Culture: Sex, Media and the Democratisation of Desire'' (2002) praised this period of Madonna's career, saying that she had "porno elegance" and that "''Sex'' is a cultural phenomenon of global proportions and thanks to this Madonna established her iconic status and cultural influence".<ref name="McNair">{{harvnb|McNair|2002|p=267}}</ref> Priya Elan from ''[[The Guardian]]'', wrote: "That the ''Sex'' book came after a record-breaking album and [[Blond Ambition World Tour|tour]] felt like a shrinkwrapped curve ball. But Madge was expressing something unique". Elan felt that the book was part of a "slower reveal that began with confessional tracks such as '[[Oh Father]]' (from 1989's ''Like a Prayer'') and continued with the many scenes of narcissism captured in [the documentary] ''[[In Bed With Madonna]]''".<ref name=Guardian/>
== Legacy == ''Sex'' is now considered a bold, [[post-feminist]], work of art,<ref name="EMOL bio">{{cite web|url=http://www.emol.com/especiales/madonna/biografias3.htm|title=Madonna sin límites|accessdate=December 6, 2012|language=Spanish|publisher=El sitio de noticias online de Chile|trans-title=Madonna without Limits|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924011717/http://www.emol.com/especiales/madonna/biografias3.htm|archivedate=September 24, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Chancer">{{harvnb|Chancer |1998|p=98}}</ref><ref name="Sex Gawker">{{cite web|url=http://gawker.com/5953385/madonnas-pussy-is-the-temple-of-learning-erotica-at-20 |title=Madonna's Pussy Is the Temple of Learning: Erotica at 20 |date=October 20, 2012 |accessdate=December 8, 2012 |first=Juzwiak |last=Rich |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121206014755/http://gawker.com/5953385/madonnas-pussy-is-the-temple-of-learning-erotica-at-20 |archivedate=December 6, 2012 |df= }}</ref> besides being labeled a "cultural book". [[Martin Amis]] from ''[[The Observer]]'' wrote an essay discussing the book's cultural meaning.<ref name="McNair" /> [[Critical theorist]] [[Douglas Kellner]] affirmed that with ''Sex'' "Madonna became herself, an artifact of [[popular culture|pop culture]]".<ref name="Kellner"/> French academic writer [[Georges Claude Guilbert]] (author of three books about Madonna) described ''Sex'' as one of the most successful publicity stunts in history<ref name="Claude Guilbert">{{harvnb|Doty|2004|p=45}}</ref> whereas Russell W. Belk, author of ''Handbook of Qualitative Research Methods in Marketing'', mentioned that the book is a [[Quality (business)|quality]] product in [[marketing]].<ref name="Book 315">{{harvnb|Belk|2006|p=315}}</ref> In 1992, Madonna had generated more than US$500 million (${{formatnum:{{Inflation|US|500000000|1992}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) to Time Warner in sales of both albums and the ''Sex'' book, despite the negative feedback.<ref name="Roy Shuker">{{harvnb|Shuker|2002|p=129}}</ref> However, Taraborrelli commented in his book, ''[[Madonna: An Intimate Biography]]'', that those "who knew Madonna well at that time, knew what was really going on with her: the ''Sex'' book—and the outrageous antics that preceded it and would follow it—was really just something she used as a barrier between her and the rest of the world."<ref name="tara232" /> For years it had seemed to Madonna that both her personal and professional life was extremely scrutinized by the public and media, and although she had started this scrutinizing by her provocative works, she was tired of it.<ref name="tara232" /> Being vexed at this interest in her personal life, Madonna fought back by creating the persona of a renegade, something so outrageous as to defy explanation, something found objectionable by most people. Taraborrelli said that in Madonna's view, "she had no other way of fighting back".<ref name="tara232" /> ''[[The Boston Globe]]''{{'}}s Matthew Gilbert analyzed the singer's provocative attempt in an article published in the newspaper:
{{quote|Madonna's motive for baring her breasts to the public feels more like personal gratification, less like commitment to a cause. She's not out to change the world. Let's face it: Few people get erotic in front of millions of viewers for purely selfless political reasons. It's hard to escape the view of Madonna as a difficult Catholic adolescent aiming the finger at everything repressive. And many of her songs are addressed to an authority figure of her youth – from God and Jesus Christ to her own father. The heart of Madonna's outrageousness seems to lie beneath her liberal rationales, as if she's acting out something private and the world is her couch, not to mention her bank. Her politics are largely Electral.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/boston/access/61869989.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+11%2C+1992&author=Matthew+Gilbert%2C+Globe+Staff&pub=Boston+Globe+(pre-1997+Fulltext)&desc=Playing+the+shock+market+Madonna+is+about+to+launch+a+multimedia+line+of+product+that+is+her+most+risque+yet.+Are+we+still+buying+it%3F&pqatl=google|title=Playing the shock market Madonna is about to launch a multimedia line of product that is her most risque yet. Are we still buying it?|date=October 10, 1992|accessdate=June 8, 2013|work=[[Boston Globe]]}}</ref>}}
According to some writers, ''Sex'' also helped Madonna make a name in the [[porn industry]],<ref name="Kirk Davidson" /> and earned her the title of [[Sadomasochism|S&M]]'s first [[cultural ambassador]]<ref name="Nyissue SM">{{cite journal|date=November 18, 1994|title=S&M offers a safe haven for ex "classy" topless bars|journal=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|page=40|volume=27|issue=47|issn=0028-7369|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XeMCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA41}}</ref> and was praised for recreating "porn-chic".<ref name="Sex and Society">{{harvnb|Cavendish|2009|p=524}}</ref> Humberto Quiroga Lavié pointed out that it was the fact that ''Sex'' was considered pornographic that helped it become a [[bestseller]].<ref name="Ensayo Judicial">{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=q0jh_O-065AC&pg=PT1443&dq=Madonna+y+su+libro+Sex&hl=es&sa=X&ei=3-rHULHlNomj2QW4ooGoDQ&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAw|title=Secretos y Misterios de Hombres y Mujeres |last=Quiroga Lavié |first=Humberto |date=|accessdate=December 11, 2012|format=essay |language=Spanish |trans-title=Secrets and Mysteries of men and women }}</ref> Steve Bachmann, on his book ''Simulating Sex: Aesthetic Representations of Erotic Activity'' pointed out that "perhaps one of the most interesting aspects of Madonna's sexual phenomenon is the extent to which her book marked a new threshold in the pornographic franchise".<ref name="Bachman 2">{{harvnb|Bachmann|2002|p=77}}</ref> McNair wrote in his book that "''Sex'' brought out the personal underground to the surface of pop culture".<ref name="McNair" /> London art critic [[Sarah Kent]] wrote in ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]'' magazine that the timing of ''Sex'' was "impeccable.<ref name="brien238" /> Obsessions about the human body was in vogue, with Madonna's book as well as artist [[Andres Serrano]]'s "[[Ejaculation|cumming shots]]" and [[Jeff Koons]]' ''The Jeff Koons Handbook'', the latter portrayed fairytale pictures of the artist having sex with his pornographic actor wife, [[Ilona Staller|Cicciolina]].<ref name="brien238" />
''Sex'' has also become an important book in the [[LGBT]] community. [[Ben Shapiro]], author of ''Porn Generation: How Social Liberalism Is Corrupting Our Future'', wrote that due to its iconic status "''Sex'' adorns the coffee tables of hundreds of gay men and [[sperm bank]]s".<ref name="Shapiro">{{Harvnb|Shapiro|2005|p=52}}</ref> [[Mark Blankenship]], from the LGBT-oriented website New Now Next stated that "literature changed forever" with the publishing of ''Sex''.<ref name="NewNowNext">{{cite web|url=http://www.newnownext.com/madonna-sex-boo/10/2012/|title=My Weird Journey With Madonna's 'Sex' Book|date=October 22, 2012|accessdate=December 7, 2012|last=Blankenship|first=Mark|publisher=Newnownext.com. [[Logo TV]]|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130831025639/http://www.newnownext.com/madonna-sex-boo/10/2012/|archivedate=August 31, 2013}}</ref> Madonna's portrayal of [[lesbian]] love scenes in the book sparked debates about her own sexual orientation.<ref name=obrien243>{{harvnb|O'Brien|2008|pp=243–245}}</ref> This was an adjunct to the singer's public relationship with comedian [[Sandra Bernhard]], with whom she cavorted around, visiting lesbian night-clubs as well as partying. The LGBT community felt it was an important portrayal for them. They debated whether Madonna was "ripping" them off for publicity. As Carolin Grace from ''[[Diva (magazine)|Diva]]'' magazine noted: "Madonna became meaningful in early nineties, when ''Sex'' came out, and at that point lesbian culture was really changing."<ref name=obrien243 /> She noted how women were coming out about their sexuality and the book's handling of the taboo issue were "a legacy, our contribution to the show. The lesbian sub-cultural references borrowed by Madonna aren't our only possessions."<ref name=obrien243 /> O'Brien argues in her book ''[[Madonna: Like an Icon]]'', that the book had a confusing philosophy. According to the female critics, who pointed out the vacuousness of Madonna's remarks about porn and abuse, the singer did not have a correct idea that behind these fantasies the "reality is too hard for her to endure", referring to the daily hustles that women have to face at red light districts and brothels.<ref>{{harvnb|O'Brien|2008|p=251}}</ref> The author felt that despite the courageous premise of genuine exploration of queer sex, the book crossed over into pornography and a wrong portrayal for the community, while being flippant and commercial.<ref name="obr252" /> She drew an example of the death of pornographic actor Joey Stefano, one of the models of the book, from drug overdose. Stefano had been thrilled to be a part of the book, but was underpaid. Once Madonna and her team were done with the shoot, "they packed up and left the [[Gaiety Theatre, New York (male burlesque)|Gaiety]]... They left behind the mundane reality and the boys who have to deal with it seven days a week."<ref name="obr252">{{harvnb|O'Brien|2008|p=252}}</ref>
== In popular culture ==
''Sex'' has also become an object of modern culture references. American [[performance artist]] [[Ann Magnuson]], who had worked with Madonna on the 1985 film ''[[Desperately Seeking Susan]]'', released a [[parody]] of the book's photo sessions, where she simulated sex with a giant [[stuffed toy|stuffed bear]].<ref name="Schneider">{{harvnb|Schneider|1997|pp=108–114}}</ref> In 2010, writer-performer [[Greg Scarnici]] released a book parody of ''Sex'', titled ''Sex in Drag'', which featured over 70 parodied images from the book.<ref name="Greg Scarnici Sex in Drag">{{cite web|url=http://www.sexindrag.com/PEEP.html|title=Sex in Drag|accessdate=December 14, 2012|first=Scarnici|last=Greg|authorlink=Greg Scarnici|publisher=SexinDrag.com|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121231124738/http://www.sexindrag.com/PEEP.html|archivedate=December 31, 2012}}</ref> In a deleted scene from a 1993 episode (''[[Krusty Gets Kancelled]]'') of the animated sitcom ''[[The Simpsons]]'', aired as part of ''[[The Simpsons 138th Episode Spectacular]]'', [[Krusty the Clown]] attempts to market a book extremely similar to ''Sex'' as a means of resolving his financial woes. {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=March 2018}} '''Sindhu Darshan Festival''' is a festival of [[India]] held every year on full moon day (on [[Guru Purnima]]) in June. It is held at [[Leh]], in [[Ladakh]] District of [[Jammu & Kashmir]]. It stretches for three days. It was first started in the October, 1997 and continues to be held every year since then, attracting large number of foreign and domestic tourists.
The Sindhu Darshan Festival is a celebration of River Sindhu, also known as the Indus Valley Civilisation. The main reason behind the celebration of Sindhu Darshan Festival is to endorse the [[Indus]] River (Sindhu River) as an icon of the communal harmony and unity of India. The Bollywood film Dil Se was shot during the first Sindhi Darshan Festival.<ref>[http://www.ladakhs.com/ladakh-festival.php]</ref>
==The beginnings== Lal Krishna Advani and Tarun Vijay a veteran journalist re-discovered the [[Sindhu]] river flowing through Ladakh, when they visited Leh in January 1996. Vijay conceived the idea of a festival on its banks as it has given the identity to India as the names India, Indian, Hindu and Hindustan are derived from indus and Sindhu. Since then it has been attracting people from all walks of life, castes, reliogions and places specially becoming a pilgrimage for Hindu Sindhis, who in pre-partition days, used to worship her ( in [[Sindh]] ), now in [[Pakistan]]. For, the purpose that, people of India, know the importance of Sindhu River, [[Lal Krishna Advani]], in 1996, himself a Sindhi, visited Choglamsar ( 8 km from Leh ) and started Sindhu Darshan Abhiyan, with handful of [[Sindhi people|Sindhi]]s.<ref name=A>[https://books.google.com/books?id=gl1bi9duptQC&pg=PA129&lpg=PA129&dq=sindhu+darshan+festival+Atal+Bihari+Vajpayee&source=bl&ots=BUwEv9zhuM&sig=kOE4nvgaQAEPRARzGaZUA-f6AdE&hl=en&ei=oDc5TceDC4LTrQfPl6TlCA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CB8Q6AEwAQ#v=snippet&q=sindhu%20darshan&f=false] Development of Ladakh Himalaya: recent researches By Prem Singh Jina. Pages : 129 to 132.</ref>
The first time this event was held in form of ''Sindhu Darshan Festival'' was in October, 1997.
==Year 2000 Sindhu Darshan Festival== Later on in year 2000, on 7 June, Sindhu Darshan Festival was held with much pomp and show and was inaugurated by [[Atal Bihari Vajpayee]], then the Prime Minister of India at [[Shey]] (15 km away from [[Leh]]).The Prime Minister laid the foundation stone of the Sindhu Cultural Center and also inaugurated the new office complex of Ladakh Autonomous Hill Development Council.<ref name=A/>
The Prime Minister, Atal Bihari Vajpayee, said ''"Some people queried about existence of Sindhu in India as described in our [[Indian National Anthem|national anthem]] but little did they know that it flows from our soil in Ladakh."'' He further added : ''"Sindhu symbolised 5,000 years ethos of Indian civilization and its re-discovery will strengthen emotional integration of country."'' and quoted hymn from [[Rig Veda]]: "Sindhu it might surpasses all the streams that flow - His roar is lifted up to heaven above the earth, he puts forth endless vigour with a flash of light, even as cow with milk rush to their calves, so other rivers roar in to Sindhu. As warrior king leads other warriors, so does Sindhu lead other rivers. Rich in good steed is Sindhu, rich in gold, nobly fashioned rich in ample wealth."<ref name=A/>
The occasion, was also marked by immersion of waters from [[Brahmaputra]] brought by [[Arunachal Pradesh]] Chief Minister, Mukut Mithi. Brahmputra & Sindhu, both rivers rise from same source in [[Mansarovar]].<ref name=A/>
==Festivities==
Every year, a large number of participants from different parts of the country participate in Sindhu Darshan Festival. They bring water from the river of their own state in earthenware pots and immerse these pots in the Sindhu River.
The first day of the Sindhu Darshan Festival witnesses a reception ceremony for the participants, organized on the banks of Sindhu at [[Shey]]. This reception ceremony is conducted by a joint association of committees of various religious groups ( [[Buddhist]], [[Shia]], [[Sunni]], [[Christian]], [[Hindu]] and [[Sikh]] ) namely, Ladakh Buddhist Association, Shia Majlis, Sunni Anjuman, Christian Moravian Church, Hindu Trust and Sikh Gurudwara Prabhandak Committee, to promote national integrity. As a part of the ritual, fifty senior [[Lama]]s conduct a prayer on the banks of the river. A series of cultural programs is also presented by the artists from various states of the country. A sightseeing tour is organised for the participants and the day comes to an end with a bonfire at night. After the cultural programmes and sightseeing trip, a [[Puja (Hinduism)|Puja]] is organized on the second day of the Sindhu Darshan Festival. On the third day, the participants get ready for the departure. [[Leh]] is popular with tourists, who visit the hill town to be a part of this grand celebrations.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.indobase.com/events/details/sindhu-darshan-festival.php |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-01-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101211160339/http://www.indobase.com/events/details/sindhu-darshan-festival.php |archivedate=11 December 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref><ref>[http://www.festivalsofindia.in/sindhu/index.aspx]</ref><ref>[http://www.fountainheadindia.com/festivals_details.php]</ref><ref>[http://www.buzzle.com/articles/sindhu-darshan-festival-in-ladakh.html]{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref>
==Postage stamp== The Postal Department of Government of India issued a postage stamp depicting Sindhu Darshan Festival on 28 July 1999. The project 'Sindhu Darshan', was started to focus attention on the heritage of the ancient Indian Civilization and Culture that 'Sindhu' symbolizes. It aims to celebrate the Sindhu as a symbol of this country's ethnic diversity and to promote communal harmony. Further, attention is sought to be focused on cultural and topographical beauty of the landscape of Ladakh. These aspects are sought to be blended in the design of the [[First day cover|First Day Cover]] which also carries inscription of the hymn '[[mantra]]', chanted by Buddhists in the area, a prayer in praise of God. The stamp depicts a landscape in the upper reaches of the Sindhu with an inset of the 'Vrishabha' (bull) [[Indus valley seals and scripts|seal of the Indus Valley Civilization]] and a line, from the '[[Rig Veda]]', describing the Sindhu.
